template.name: AWS_Industrial IoT with AWS IoT Greengrass
template.desc:
Hybrid network connectivity from a data center to the AWS Cloud

AWS offers an IoT extension called AWS IoT Greengrass. AWS IoT Greengrass devices can work autonomously on-premises, and in disconnected mode from the internet and AWS. The primary function of AWS IoT Greengrass is to act as a proxy or a buffer between edge devices or IoT sensors and the AWS Cloud. Additionally, it is possible to run Docker containers, use AWS Lambda functions, and run inference models using Amazon SageMaker AI. 

AWS IoT Greengrass can communicate with AWS IoT Core using public networks, such as the internet, as well as through Site-to-Site VPN or Direct Connect (refer to the dotted arrows in the preceding figure). Connectivity through Site-to-Site VPN or Direct Connect helps customers to not expose their local factory networks to the public internet, for safety and security reasons. By using VPC endpoints, customers can enable their devices to connect to AWS IoT Core using an endpoint that resolves to a private IP address within their VPC subnet. In addition, customers can restrict access to IoT Core to allow only connections over their VPC endpoint.

trustZone.name: Intranet Office networks
trustZone.desc: All intranet subnets allocated to user campuses, with exception of DC LAN.

dataflow.name: AWS VPC Endpoint -> AWS IoT Core
AWS IoT Greengrass -> AWS VPC Endpoint
Site-to-Site VPN -> Local On-Premise Data Center
Local On-Premise Data Center -> Site-to-Site VPN
AWS IoT Greengrass -> AWS IoT Core

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-330
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-330: Use of Insufficiently Random Values The product uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers. When product generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

countermeasure.name: Assign unique identities to each device
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that each IoT device is assigned a unique identity to prevent conflicts and ensure secure connections with AWS IoT Core. This helps in managing devices individually and maintaining secure and reliable communication.

Assign Unique Client IDs:

  • Generate and assign unique client IDs for each IoT device during the provisioning process to ensure individual identification and prevent identity conflicts.

Use Unique Certificates:

  • Issue unique X.509 certificates to each device for authentication purposes. This ensures that each device can be individually verified and trusted.

Implement Device-Specific Policies:

  • Create and apply fine-grained IoT policies that are specific to each device, limiting their permissions to only what is necessary for their operation.

Monitor Device Connections:

  • Regularly monitor device connections and logs to detect any identity conflicts or unauthorized access attempts.

reference.name: Use a single identity per device

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Ensure devices validate server certificates
countermeasure.desc:
Configure IoT devices to validate server certificates to confirm they are connecting to AWS IoT Core and not a malicious server. This practice is essential for preventing man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks and ensuring secure communication.

Enable Certificate Validation:

  • Configure IoT devices to check the validity of server certificates presented by AWS IoT Core during the TLS handshake process. Ensure devices are programmed to reject connections if the certificate validation fails.

Use Trusted Certificate Authorities:

  • Ensure that devices trust certificates issued by trusted Certificate Authorities (CAs). Include the CA certificates in the device firmware or configuration.

Regularly Update Trusted Certificates:

  • Keep the list of trusted CA certificates up-to-date on all IoT devices to ensure they recognize new or updated AWS IoT Core certificates.

Monitor Certificate Status:

  • Implement mechanisms to monitor and log the status of certificate validation attempts. This helps in identifying and responding to potential security issues promptly.

countermeasure.name: Implement cross-service confused deputy prevention techniques
countermeasure.desc:
Implement cross-service confused deputy prevention techniques to ensure that AWS IoT Device Advisor operates securely and only performs authorized actions.

Use IAM Policies with sts:ExternalId:

  • When granting permissions to AWS IoT Device Advisor, include the sts:ExternalId condition in IAM policies to prevent unauthorized services from assuming roles intended for Device Advisor.

Scope Down Permissions:

  • Define IAM policies with the minimum necessary permissions for Device Advisor to perform its functions. Avoid granting broad permissions that could be exploited.

Enable Logging and Monitoring:

  • Enable AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch logging for actions performed by Device Advisor. Regularly review logs to detect any unusual or unauthorized activity.

Periodic Policy Reviews:

  • Regularly review and update IAM policies to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege and incorporate any new security best practices.

reference.name: Cross-service confused deputy prevention for Device Advisor

countermeasure.name: Implement just-in-time provisioning for device setup
countermeasure.desc:
Automate the setup of IoT devices by implementing just-in-time (JIT) provisioning when they first connect to AWS IoT Core. This streamlines the device onboarding process, reduces manual errors, and ensures consistent configuration.

Configure JIT Provisioning:

  • Set up JIT provisioning in AWS IoT Core by defining a provisioning template that specifies the necessary device attributes and policies.
  • Ensure that the template includes details such as IoT policies, certificates, and any required attributes.

Enable JIT Provisioning on Devices:

  • Configure IoT devices to support JIT provisioning, ensuring they request provisioning upon their initial connection to AWS IoT Core.

Monitor and Validate:

  • Monitor the provisioning process to ensure that devices are being set up correctly and efficiently.
  • Validate that all necessary security policies and configurations are applied during the provisioning process.

Regular Updates:

  • Keep the provisioning templates updated to reflect any changes in security policies or device requirements.

countermeasure.name: Implement NTP clients for device clock synchronization
countermeasure.desc:
Configure NTP clients on all IoT devices to synchronize their clocks with reliable time servers. This ensures accurate time for certificate validation and secure communication with AWS IoT Core.

Install NTP Client:

  • Install an appropriate NTP client on your device.

Configure NTP Servers:

  • Set the NTP client to use reliable NTP servers.

Enable and Start NTP Service:

  • Ensure the NTP service is enabled and starts on boot.

Monitor Synchronization:

  • Regularly check synchronization status and logs to ensure accurate timekeeping.

reference.name: Keep your device's clock in sync

countermeasure.name: Secure MQTT connections with TLS encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all MQTT connections between IoT devices and AWS IoT Core are secured using TLS encryption. This protects data in transit from interception and unauthorized access.

Enable TLS Encryption:

  • Configure IoT devices to use TLS for all MQTT connections to AWS IoT Core.

Use Valid Certificates:

  • Ensure devices use valid X.509 certificates for establishing TLS connections. Certificates should be issued by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).

Verify Server Certificates:

  • Configure devices to verify the server certificates presented by AWS IoT Core to prevent man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Regularly Update Certificates:

  • Periodically update certificates and TLS configurations to comply with the latest security standards and practices.

reference.name: Protecting MQTT connections in AWS IoT

countermeasure.name: Store data in a second AWS segion for backup
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure data availability and resilience by storing a copy of your data in a second AWS region. This practice mitigates the risk of data loss or service disruption in the event of a regional failure.

Configure Cross-Region Replication:

  • Set up cross-region replication for your data storage (e.g., Amazon S3 buckets) to automatically replicate data to a backup region.

Automate Data Backup:

  • Use AWS Backup or custom automation scripts to regularly back up databases and other critical data to a secondary region.

Test Disaster Recovery:

  • Periodically test your disaster recovery processes to ensure that data can be successfully restored from the backup region.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Implement monitoring and auditing to verify that backups are occurring as scheduled and data integrity is maintained.

reference.name: Use a second AWS Region as backup

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single region failure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Single region failure refers to the risk of an AWS region hosting IoT Core infrastructure becoming unavailable due to natural disasters, technical failures, or cyber-attacks, causing service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Natural disasters
    • Technical failures
    • Cyber-attacks
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Infrastructure vulnerabilities
    • Lack of redundancy
    • Single points of failure

Impacts

  • Availability: Loss of IoT service availability
  • Data Integrity: Potential data loss or corruption
  • Reputation: Damage to customer trust and company reputation
  • Financial: Financial losses due to downtime

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Natural Disaster:
    • An earthquake disrupts the data center in a specific AWS region, causing an outage of IoT services.
  2. Technical Failure:
    • A power outage in the region leads to a failure of IoT Core services, disconnecting IoT devices.
  3. Cyber Attack:
    • A DDoS attack targets the region's infrastructure, rendering IoT Core services unavailable.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confused deputy problem
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The Confused Deputy Problem occurs when a service with higher privileges is tricked by an unauthorized entity into performing actions on its behalf. In AWS IoT Core, this can happen if a service like Device Advisor, which has broad permissions, is exploited to access or modify resources without proper authorization.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting a service with high-level permissions
    • Leveraging improperly configured IAM roles or policies
    • Tricking a service into performing unintended actions

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Integrity: Unintended modifications to data or configurations
  • Availability: Potential disruption of IoT services
  • Reputation: Damage to trust and reputation due to security breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Service Exploitation:
    • An attacker exploits Device Advisor, which has high-level permissions, to access and modify IoT device configurations, causing unauthorized changes and data breaches.
  2. Improper IAM Configuration:
    • A misconfigured IAM role allows an attacker to use Device Advisor to perform actions on resources that they should not have access to, leading to data manipulation or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure MQTT connections
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure MQTT connections occur when MQTT communication between IoT devices and AWS IoT Core is not properly secured, potentially allowing unauthorized access and data interception. MQTT, a lightweight messaging protocol commonly used in IoT, can be vulnerable if not encrypted or authenticated adequately.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Cybercriminals
    • Malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted MQTT communication
    • Weak or missing authentication mechanisms
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks
    • Exploitation of open ports and network vulnerabilities

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data transmitted between IoT devices and AWS IoT Core.
  • Integrity: Potential tampering with data or commands being sent to and from IoT devices.
  • Availability: Disruption of IoT services through malicious interference or unauthorized command execution.
  • Reputation: Loss of trust and credibility due to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Communication:
    • An attacker intercepts MQTT messages sent over an unencrypted channel, gaining access to sensitive data such as device status and control commands.
  2. MitM Attack:
    • A cybercriminal positions themselves between an IoT device and AWS IoT Core, intercepting and altering MQTT messages to manipulate device behavior or steal data.
  3. Weak Authentication:
    • An attacker exploits weak or default credentials to connect to the MQTT broker, allowing unauthorized access to the IoT system and the ability to send malicious commands.

threat.name: Untrusted server connections
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Untrusted server connections occur when IoT devices connect to servers that are not verified as legitimate. This can lead to man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks where an attacker intercepts and possibly alters the communication between the IoT devices and AWS IoT Core. Ensuring server authenticity is critical to maintaining the security and integrity of data transmitted between IoT devices and cloud services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Cybercriminals
    • Malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • MitM attacks through DNS spoofing or ARP poisoning
    • Connecting to malicious or compromised servers
    • Exploitation of unverified server certificates

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data transmitted between IoT devices and servers.
  • Integrity: Potential tampering with data being communicated, leading to incorrect device behavior or corrupted data.
  • Availability: Disruption of service due to interception and alteration of commands or data.
  • Reputation: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to security breaches and compromised data integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

MitM Attack:

  • An attacker intercepts communication between an IoT device and AWS IoT Core by spoofing the DNS. The attacker redirects the device to a malicious server, capturing sensitive data and possibly sending false commands to the device.

Compromised Server Certificate:

  • An IoT device connects to a server with a compromised or forged certificate. The attacker uses this connection to access data sent by the device or to send malicious instructions to the device.

DNS Spoofing:

  • An attacker manipulates the DNS response to redirect IoT devices to a rogue server under their control. This allows the attacker to monitor and alter the communication between the devices and the legitimate AWS IoT Core.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Device identity conflicts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Device identity conflicts occur when multiple IoT devices use the same client ID to connect to AWS IoT Core. This conflict can lead to connectivity issues, unauthorized access, and potential data corruption as AWS IoT Core struggles to manage and authenticate multiple devices presenting the same identity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Malicious insiders
    • Negligent or uninformed developers
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Reusing client IDs across multiple devices
    • Misconfiguration of device provisioning processes
    • Exploiting lack of unique identity enforcement in device firmware or software

Impacts

  • Availability: Devices may be disconnected frequently as AWS IoT Core detects and tries to resolve the identity conflicts, leading to service disruptions.
  • Integrity: Data from one device may be confused with data from another, leading to potential data corruption or inaccurate readings.
  • Security: Unauthorized devices could gain access to the system by presenting a valid client ID that is already in use, compromising the security of the network.
  • Reputation: Persistent connectivity and data integrity issues can damage customer trust and the reputation of the service provider.

Example Attack Scenarios

Reused Client IDs:

  • A manufacturer incorrectly configures multiple IoT devices with the same client ID during the production process. When these devices attempt to connect to AWS IoT Core, they repeatedly disconnect and reconnect, causing significant disruption in service and data flow.

Unauthorized Access:

  • An attacker discovers a valid client ID used by a legitimate device and configures a rogue device to use the same ID. This causes the legitimate device to be repeatedly disconnected, while the attacker gains unauthorized access to the network.

Provisioning Errors:

  • During the device provisioning process, an error in the script assigns the same client ID to multiple devices. These devices then compete for connection, leading to frequent disconnections and unreliable service.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Clock drift issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Clock drift issues occur when the internal clocks of IoT devices lose synchronization with real-world time, leading to inaccuracies. This can cause problems in authenticating with AWS IoT Core, validating certificates, and ensuring the correct sequence of events.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Device manufacturers
    • Device software developers
    • Environmental factors affecting device hardware
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Lack of real-time clock (RTC) synchronization mechanisms
    • Prolonged disconnection from network time sources
    • Battery depletion in devices with RTCs
    • Firmware or software bugs affecting timekeeping

Impacts

  • Availability: Devices may fail to connect to AWS IoT Core if their clock drifts too far from the actual time, resulting in service interruptions.
  • Integrity: Time-sensitive operations and data logging may be affected, leading to inaccurate data records.
  • Security: Expired or not-yet-valid certificates may be incorrectly validated, exposing the system to potential security threats.
  • Compliance: Failure to maintain accurate time can affect regulatory compliance, especially in sectors that require precise timekeeping.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Authentication Failures:
    • An IoT device with significant clock drift attempts to connect to AWS IoT Core. Due to the inaccurate time, the TLS handshake fails, preventing the device from authenticating and connecting.
  2. Certificate Validation Issues:
    • Devices with unsynchronized clocks may incorrectly treat valid certificates as expired or reject certificates that are not yet valid, leading to connectivity issues and potential security vulnerabilities.
  3. Data Logging Errors:
    • An IoT device logs data with incorrect timestamps due to clock drift. This results in a mismatch in time-sensitive data, affecting analytics and decision-making processes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion

threat.name: Manual device provisioning errors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Manual device provisioning errors occur when the process of manually setting up IoT devices introduces mistakes or inconsistencies. This can lead to misconfigurations, security vulnerabilities, and operational inefficiencies. Manual provisioning is prone to human error, such as incorrect settings, overlooked steps, or inconsistent configurations across devices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Device manufacturers
    • System integrators
    • Field technicians
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Typographical errors during manual entry
    • Inconsistent configuration steps
    • Lack of standardized provisioning procedures
    • Inadequate training of personnel responsible for device setup

Impacts

  • Availability: Devices may fail to connect or operate correctly, leading to service disruptions.
  • Integrity: Inconsistent configurations can lead to unreliable device behavior and data inconsistencies.
  • Security: Misconfigurations can introduce vulnerabilities, such as improper authentication or unauthorized access.
  • Operational Efficiency: Increased time and resources spent on troubleshooting and correcting manual provisioning errors.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Security Settings:
    • A technician manually configures the security settings on an IoT device but inadvertently skips a step, leaving the device vulnerable to unauthorized access.
  2. Inconsistent Device Configurations:
    • Different technicians provision devices with slight variations in settings, leading to inconsistent performance and data integrity issues.
  3. Typographical Errors:
    • During manual entry of device IDs and credentials, a technician makes a typographical error, resulting in the device being unable to authenticate and connect to AWS IoT Core.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-345
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Cipher suite recommendations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of data in transit within your AWS IoT Greengrass environment, it is crucial to use strong and recommended cipher suites. This practice helps ensure the integrity and confidentiality of your data as it moves between devices, AWS IoT Greengrass core devices, and AWS cloud services.

Follow these steps to implement the recommended cipher suites:

  1. Refer to the AWS IoT Greengrass V2 Security Best Practices document to identify the recommended cipher suites.
  2. Update the communication configuration of your devices and AWS IoT Greengrass core devices to only allow these strong cipher suites. This may involve modifying configuration files and settings in your IoT devices and AWS IoT Greengrass core software.
  3. Ensure that all client and server devices involved in communication support and are configured to use the selected cipher suites.
  4. Regularly review and update your configurations to include new cipher suites as recommended by AWS security guidelines. This will help to protect your communication links against evolving threats.
  5. Test the communication to verify that only the strong and recommended cipher suites are being used. This can involve validating the configuration using tools and logs to check the cipher suites being negotiated during communication.

By strictly adhering to these steps and regularly updating your configurations, you can effectively protect data in transit in your AWS IoT Greengrass environment. For further details, refer to the AWS IoT Greengrass V2 Security Best Practices.

countermeasure.name: Do not hardcode credentials in Greengrass components
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS IoT Greengrass deployments, it is crucial to avoid hardcoding credentials within your application code or configuration files. Instead, leverage AWS Secrets Manager or AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store to manage and retrieve credentials securely.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Use AWS Secrets Manager or AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store:
    • AWS Secrets Manager: This service allows you to rotate, manage, and retrieve credentials, API keys, and other secrets. Store your secrets in AWS Secrets Manager and use AWS SDKs to programmatically retrieve these secrets when needed. For more information, see the AWS Secrets Manager User Guide.
    • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store: This service provides secure, hierarchical storage for configuration data management and secrets management. Parameters can be stored as plain text or encrypted data. More details can be found in the AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store User Guide.
  2. Configure IAM Policies:
    • Ensure that your Greengrass core device role has the necessary permissions to access the secrets stored in AWS Secrets Manager or parameters stored in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Define specific IAM policies that grant read access only to the required secrets or parameters. Refer to the service role policies for more information.
  3. Retrieve Secrets Programmatically:
    • Use the AWS SDKs to retrieve secrets or parameters at runtime within your Greengrass components. This ensures that credentials and sensitive information are never hardcoded or exposed within the application.

This approach not only secures your credentials but also simplifies the process of rotating credentials without significant changes to your application code. For more detailed security best practices, please refer to the AWS IoT Greengrass V2 Security Best Practices.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Do not log sensitive information
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that logs do not contain sensitive information such as passwords, API keys, or tokens, it is vital to implement secure logging practices as recommended in the AWS IoT Greengrass V2 Security Best Practices.

Follow the steps below to achieve this:

  1. Identify Sensitive Information:

    Determine what constitutes sensitive information in your context, including but not limited to passwords, API keys, tokens, and personally identifiable information (PII).

  2. Configure Logging Providers:

    When using AWS IoT Greengrass, configure logging providers to exclude sensitive information. Adjust log levels to avoid verbose outputs that might inadvertently include sensitive data. Refer to the Configure logs section.

  3. Use Logging Libraries:

    Leverage well-established logging libraries that offer redaction features. These libraries can help in sanitizing log outputs to exclude sensitive information.

  4. Review and Scrub Logs:

    Regularly review the logs to ensure no sensitive information is being captured. Set up a process for automatic log scrubbing to remove any inadvertent inclusion of sensitive data before logs are stored or transmitted.

  5. Access Control:

    Implement strict access controls for log files to limit exposure. Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to restrict who can access logs. Refer to the Security considerations: Core device permissions section for detailed guidance.

By following these steps, cloud engineers can significantly mitigate the risk of exposing sensitive information in logs while utilizing AWS IoT Greengrass.

For additional information, visit the official AWS IoT Greengrass V2 Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Grant minimum possible permissions
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that IAM policies grant only the permissions required for AWS IoT Greengrass components to function effectively and securely, it is crucial to follow the principle of least privilege. This countermeasure involves creating and deploying IAM policies that provide the minimum necessary permissions for each Greengrass component.

First, identify all the Greengrass components and services that your deployment requires to function. You should map out each component's specific permissions based on its operational needs. AWS provides detailed guidelines and examples of these required permissions in the Greengrass security best practices documentation.

Here is a step-by-step approach to implement this control:

  1. Create an IAM policy that specifies only the required actions for each Greengrass component. For instance, you may need to grant permissions for publishing messages, subscribing to topics, or interacting with other AWS services. Refer to the minimum required permissions section to understand the specific needs.
  2. Assign the created policy to an IAM role that the Greengrass component will assume. This involves updating the components configuration to use this IAM role.
  3. Regularly review and update the IAM policies to ensure they only contain permissions necessary for the current operation of the Greengrass components. Remove any permissions that are no longer needed.
  4. Monitor the usage of assigned permissions using AWS CloudTrail logs to ensure no unnecessary permissions are being exploited. This will help in identifying any deviations from the least privilege principle.
  5. Conduct periodic audits and assessments to validate that your IAM policies remain aligned with the principle of least privilege and comply with the AWS IoT Greengrass security best practices.

By implementing these steps, you ensure that your IAM policies are tightly scoped and provide only the necessary permissions for your AWS IoT Greengrass components to function, thereby enhancing the overall security of your Greengrass deployment.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Keep your device clock in sync
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the accurate and synchronized operation of IoT devices in an AWS IoT Greengrass environment, it is crucial to maintain precise time settings. Network Time Protocol (NTP) is a reliable method to synchronize clocks across networked devices.

Implementation Guidance

Follow these steps to implement NTP for device clock synchronization in AWS IoT Greengrass:

  1. Implement NTP Configuration: Configure your IoT devices to use NTP servers to synchronize their clocks. This is essential for maintaining the integrity and reliability of timed operations within your Greengrass core devices. Here is a general approach:
    • Install NTP client software on your IoT devices if not already installed.
    • Edit the NTP configuration file (commonly /etc/ntp.conf) to include the addresses of NTP servers. For example:
      • server 0.pool.ntp.org
server 1.pool.ntp.org
server 2.pool.ntp.org
server 3.pool.ntp.org
  2. Verify Time Synchronization: Regularly check the status of the NTP client to ensure the clocks are synchronized.
    • Use commands such as ntpq -p or timedatectl status on Linux-based systems to verify NTP synchronization.
    • Check the system logs for any related errors or warnings that may indicate issues with time synchronization.
  3. Automate Time Configuration: Consider using automated scripts or AWS Systems Manager to enforce NTP configuration across all IoT devices, ensuring consistency and reducing manual efforts.

Accurate and synchronized device clocks are vital for the security and reliability of your IoT devices' communications and operations. By implementing NTP as described, you adhere to the AWS security best practices for AWS IoT Greengrass.

For more detailed information, refer to the official AWS IoT Greengrass documentation on synchronizing device clocks.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Granting excessive permissions can expose cloud resources to unauthorized access and manipulation, enlarging the attack surface and escalating the risk of significant damage if accounts are compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, either external attackers or internal users with ill intents, gain access through compromised accounts that possess more privileges than required for their function. This over-privileged access can be exploited to access sensitive data, modify settings, or perform unauthorized actions.
Impacts
Such incidents can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, financial losses, and reputational damage. Over-privileged accounts increase the likelihood of widespread impact across the system when compromised.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an employees over-privileged account via phishing and uses the excessive permissions to exfiltrate sensitive customer data. Alternatively, a disgruntled employee misuses their broad access rights to disrupt system configurations, causing service outages and operational delays.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Use of weak or insecure cipher suites
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using weak or insecure cipher suites can lead to data breaches and man-in-the-middle attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers who exploit weak encryption by intercepting data between AWS IoT Greengrass and its edge devices, or compromising the communication channels due to poorly configured cipher suites.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive information, data breaches, loss of data integrity, and potential down-time or disruption in IoT services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a weak cipher suite to decrypt secure communication between an IoT Greengrass device and its cloud services, gaining access to sensitive data or injecting malicious commands to manipulate the IoT device operations. Another scenario could involve a man-in-the-middle attack where the attacker intercepts and alters communications due to the use of insecure encryption methods, leading to data tampering or theft.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Hardcoding credentials in embedded systems or software components can lead to unintended exposure and unauthorized access if the source code becomes publicly available or compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, external hackers, or anyone with access to the source code repository. Attack vectors include accessing the source code through exposed repositories, phishing attacks to compromise developer accounts, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the deployment pipeline.
Impacts
The exposure of hardcoded credentials can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive systems, data breaches, and potential control over connected IoT devices. This can result in significant financial and reputational damage and may lead to regulatory compliance issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
An external attacker gains access to a public code repository where credentials are hardcoded in the Greengrass component. Using these credentials, the attacker accesses the AWS IoT environment, manipulates IoT device behavior, and exfiltrates sensitive data. Additionally, a phishing attack on a developer's email leads to the compromise of a private repository containing hardcoded credentials, resulting in unauthorized access to critical services.

threat.name: Logging of sensitive information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Logging sensitive information can lead to its unintentional exposure, posing significant privacy and security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized individuals gaining access to log files, either through misconfigured access controls, insider threats, or leaked storage credentials.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, leading to potential data breaches, loss of confidentiality, non-compliance with regulations such as GDPR or HIPAA, and damage to organizational reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploiting weak access controls to read log files containing confidential information like API keys, credentials, or PII. A rogue employee accessing and leaking sensitive data from logs. Mismanagement of logs resulting in publicly accessible storage that reveals customer data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1082 - System Information Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Time-based attacks and inconsistencies
threat.desc:
General threat description
If the device clock is not synchronized, it can lead to security issues such as expired certificates, log inconsistencies, and time-based attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit unsynchronized clocks to manipulate device interactions, potentially causing expired certificates to appear valid or creating discrepancies in system logs. This manipulation can facilitate the execution of time-based attacks, such as replay attacks, where attackers reuse valid data transmissions.
Impacts
The unsynchronized device clocks can lead to significant security ramifications, including the inability to verify the authenticity of certificates, difficulties in tracing security incidents due to inconsistent logs, and an increased risk of successful time-based attacks. These impacts undermine the integrity and reliability of the entire IoT system.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts and replays a valid data packet from an IoT device, exploiting the unsynchronized clock to pass off old data as new, bypassing authentication mechanisms. 2. A device attempts to connect to a server using an expired certificate, but due to time discrepancies, the server incorrectly validates the certificate, allowing unauthorized access. 3. Security analysts are unable to accurately correlate logs from distributed IoT devices during a forensic investigation, leading to incomplete or incorrect conclusions about a security breach.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-754
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-754: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions The product does not check or incorrectly checks for unusual or exceptional conditions that are not expected to occur frequently during day to day operation of the product.

weakness.name: CWE-914
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-914: Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to access arbitrary variables that are specified by an input string. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can modify unintended variables that have security implications.

countermeasure.name: Establish bidirectional communication to remote devices with secure tunneling
countermeasure.desc:
Secure tunneling in AWS IoT Device Management provides encrypted and authenticated communications between remote devices and your AWS environment. This is critical for ensuring data integrity and confidentiality during device interactions. To implement this countermeasure, follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the AWS IoT Device Management console.
  2. Set up a secure tunnel by selecting the device you wish to communicate with and initiate the tunnel setup process.
  3. Configure the secure tunneling parameters, ensuring that you enable encryption and specify the authentication methods used for device identity verification.
  4. Install the secure tunneling client software on your remote devices. This client will manage the secure communicate channel, ensuring all data transmitted is encrypted and authenticated.
  5. Document the configuration settings and key management processes, keeping them in line with recommended security practices outlined in the AWS IoT Device Management Developer Guide.
  6. Regularly monitor and audit the secure tunnels to ensure they are functioning correctly and watch for any potential anomalies or security alerts using AWS monitoring tools.
  7. Update your secure tunneling software and device firmware regularly to incorporate security patches and improvements, referencing the AWS IoT Security Best Practices.

By following these guidelines, you can ensure that communications between your AWS environment and remote devices remain secure, mitigates the risks of unauthorized access, and align with AWS's recommended security framework.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Manage and perform updates remotely
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure devices connected to AWS IoT Device Management are always running the latest security patches and features, it is crucial to enable and manage remote software updates. This countermeasure helps safeguard your IoT devices against vulnerabilities by keeping the device firmware and software up-to-date. Follow these steps to implement remote software updates:

  1. Use AWS IoT Device Management: Utilize AWS IoT Device Management's File Distribution Service to securely deliver software updates to your fleet of devices. This service allows you to distribute updates efficiently and at scale.
  2. Schedule Regular Updates: Establish a regular update schedule that aligns with your organization's patch management policy. Consistent updates ensure that devices remain protected from known vulnerabilities.
  3. Monitor Update Status: Leverage AWS IoT Device Management to monitor the status of updates. Ensure that updates are successfully applied and investigate any failures promptly. Detailed logs and metrics can help in tracking the update process.
  4. Test Updates: Before deploying updates to production devices, use a subset of test devices to validate the updates. AWS IoT Device Management allows you to create test groups, ensuring updates do not introduce new issues.
  5. Rollback Capability: Implement a rollback plan for updates in case they introduce compatibility issues or unexpected behavior. AWS IoT Device Management supports rolling back to previous versions if necessary.
  6. Security Considerations: Ensure that all communication related to software updates is encrypted and authenticated. Utilize AWS IoT Device Management's device defender capabilities to verify that devices are secure before and after updates.

For more detailed information, please refer to the official AWS IoT Device Management Features page.

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Manage software package versions
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively manage different versions of software packages deployed on IoT devices while maintaining consistency and security, leverage AWS IoT Device Management's Fleet Indexing and Search and Jobs Management features.

Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Enable Fleet Indexing: This feature allows you to index data about your devices, such as connection state and associated software versions. By enabling fleet indexing, you can efficiently search and filter devices based on these attributes. This can be invaluable for identifying devices running outdated or vulnerable software versions. Learn more.
  2. Use Jobs Management to Deploy Updates: AWS IoT Device Managements Jobs feature allows you to define, manage, and monitor OTA (Over-the-Air) updates. Schedule and monitor updates to device fleets to maintain software consistency across all devices. This ensures that all devices run secure and up-to-date software versions. Learn more.
  3. Monitor Deployment Progress: Utilize the detailed job execution reports provided by the Jobs feature. This helps keep track of deployment status, identifying any devices that failed to update correctly and may need further troubleshooting or a manual update. Learn more.
  4. Implement Device Logging: Enable logging for your IoT devices and utilize Amazon CloudWatch or AWS CloudTrail to aggregate and review these logs. This will help you track the activity and identify any issues during the deployment of software updates. Learn more.

By implementing the above steps, you can maintain software package consistency across your device fleet and ensure that all devices comply with the required security standards. These practices leverage official AWS IoT Device Management capabilities, ensuring robust management and security of your IoT devices.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

countermeasure.name: Monitor system performance
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly monitoring the performance of IoT devices is essential to ensure efficient operation and to timely identify and address performance issues. Implementing this countermeasure involves using the features provided by AWS IoT Device Management.

The following steps outline how a cloud engineer can achieve this:

  • Utilize Fleet Indexing: AWS IoT Device Management allows you to create fleet indices. Use these indices to search and filter through your fleet data effectively, helping you identify performance anomalies across your devices quickly. Refer to the AWS documentation on Fleet Indexing and Search for detailed guidance.
  • Set Up Device Shadow: Use Device Shadows to keep a virtual representation of the device's state. Monitor the current state of your devices and compare it with the desired state to detect discrepancies. More information on Device Shadows can be found in the AWS IoT Device Shadows documentation.
  • Implement AWS IoT Events: Create AWS IoT Events to monitor device data for specific performance metrics and define actions when certain thresholds are met. This proactive monitoring helps in real-time detection of performance issues, minimizing potential impacts. Refer to the AWS IoT Events guide for more details.
  • Leverage CloudWatch Integration: Integrate your IoT devices with Amazon CloudWatch to collect and track metrics, collect and monitor log files, and set alarms. This integration provides a comprehensive view of your device performance over time. For implementation advice, consult the CloudWatch integration documentation.
  • Automate with AWS IoT Job: Use AWS IoT Jobs to automate recurring management tasks such as updates, patches, and performance checks. This automation ensures that your devices are regularly maintained and up-to-date, reducing the risk of performance degradation. Detailed instructions can be found in the AWS IoT Jobs documentation.

By following these steps and utilizing the features highlighted in the official AWS documentation, cloud engineers can implement a robust system for regular monitoring of IoT device performance, leading to more efficient operations and timely identification of performance issues.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Device performance degradation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Suboptimal performance of IoT devices can lead to operational inefficiencies and potential data loss or delay.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can be misconfigured devices, outdated firmware, or poorly optimized network settings. Attack vectors can include network congestion, interference, or insufficient computational resources on the IoT device.
Impacts
The impacts include reduced operational efficiency, delayed or lost data, and potential operational disruptions. This can lead to inaccurate data analysis, delayed decision-making, and potential financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization relies on IoT devices for real-time monitoring of production lines. Due to network congestion or firmware issues, the devices underperform, causing delays in data reporting. This results in undetected production anomalies and decreased overall efficiency.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to device data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized individuals accessing device data can lead to data breaches and manipulation of device configurations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include hackers, malicious insiders, or external attackers who exploit vulnerabilities. Attack vectors could involve compromised credentials, weak access controls, or exploiting software vulnerabilities.
Impacts
Impacts include sensitive data exposure, unauthorized data alteration, operational disruptions, and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
Example scenarios may involve an attacker using stolen credentials to access the management console, a malicious insider changing device configurations to cause disruptions, or an external attacker exploiting a vulnerability to manipulate data transmitted by IoT devices.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Software vulnerabilities due to outdated versions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Running outdated software on IoT devices exposes them to known vulnerabilities and security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious actors such as hackers, cybercriminals, or even automated bots that scan for devices running outdated software. These attackers exploit known vulnerabilities that have been patched in newer software versions.
Impacts
The impacts can range from unauthorized access to sensitive data, device manipulation, service disruption, to being part of a larger botnet used for distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a known vulnerability in outdated firmware to gain control of an IoT device, leading to data theft or manipulation. Another scenario involves the attacker using the compromised device as a part of a botnet to launch a DDoS attack on a larger target, causing significant disruption to services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Enforce tagging standards on Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
Every Lambda function must carry a complete, standardized tag set for example Environment, Owner, CostCenter, and Compliance so that security, cost-allocation, and automation workflows can rely on consistent metadata.

How to implement

  1. Define the mandatory keys in a central document (e.g., tagging-standard.md) and publish it to your IaC repository.
  2. Validate in the pipeline
    • Add a build step (cfn-lint/Checkov/GitHub Action, etc.) that fails if the template or aws lambda create-function command omits any required tag.
  3. Enforce at runtime with AWS Config
    • Enable the managed rule required-tags or deploy a custom rule that checks the AWS::Lambda::Function resource type and your mandatory tag list.
    • Configure the rule for continuous evaluation and send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket.
  4. Auto-remediate or quarantine
    • Attach an EventBridge rule to run an SSM Automation or Lambda fixer script that adds missing tagsor, in strict environments, disables the function until tags are corrected.
  5. Review quarterly
    • Spot-check tag accuracy (e.g., does the Owner tag still map to an active identity?) and update the standard when new reporting requirements appear.

Automated tagging enforcement guarantees that every Lambda function can be located, costed, and governed, while eliminating drift caused by manual provisioning.

References

  • Tagging Lambda functions
  • AWS Config rule required-tags

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with perfect-forward-secrecy for all Lambda traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every network path that carries AWS Lambda control-plane or data-plane trafficCLI / SDK calls to the Lambda API, Function URLs, ALB/API Gateway invokes, VPC egress, and third-party integrationsnegotiates TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 using PFS cipher suites (ECDHE or DHE). Disable legacy SSL/TLS versions and static-key ciphers to eliminate downgrade and session-key compromise risks.

Implementation guidance

  1. Runtime & library hardening
    • Use current AWS SDKs, AWS CLI v2, and OS packages (OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181, .NET 4.6) that default to TLS 1.2+.
    • In container images or AMIs set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 and remove *_RSA_* suites from the cipher list.
  2. Outbound Lambda networking
    • When the function runs in a VPC, allow only TCP 443 to interface endpoints (S3, STS, Secrets Manager, etc.). Block port 80 in security groups and route tables.
    • For external calls, pin the destination to https:// URIs and verify certificates (e.g., with Python requests.verify=True).
  3. Inbound invoke paths
    • Function URLs: set AuthType=AWS_IAM or another auth method; TLS is auto-enforced by AWS but add a WAF rule that blocks any request with the X-Forwarded-Proto != https.
    • API Gateway / ALB: enable TLS 1.2 minimum on the custom domain or listener policy; prefer ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06.
    • For IoT or custom MQTT, use certificates that advertise only TLS 1.2/1.3 and EC cipher suites.
  4. Central guardrails
    • Attach an SCP that denies lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl or execute-api:Invoke when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy AWS Config rules or cfn-nag checks that fail if an ALB listener policy includes TLS 1.0/1.1 or if a VPC security group permits port 80 egress.
  5. Continuous verification
    • Add a CI test that attempts openssl s_client -connect lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 and expect failure; succeed with -tls1_2.
    • Scan AMIs and containers monthly with Inspector or OpenSCAP for outdated OpenSSL/LibreSSL versions.
  6. Incident response & patching
    • Subscribe to AWS Security Bulletins; redeploy all Lambda runtime layers when critical TLS CVEs are announced.
    • Rotate any function URL or API Gateway custom certificates that use deprecated algorithms (RSA-1024, SHA-1).

Following this control guarantees strong, modern encryption end-to-end, satisfying compliance frameworks and protecting Lambda workloads against passive interception and forward-decryption attacks.

References

  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum for all AWS service endpoints
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda security
