usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive permissions in endpoint policy
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
An overly permissive VPC Endpoint policy grants principals more access than intendedoften using wildcards for Principal, Action, or Resourceallowing unauthorized actors or networks to use the endpoint to reach AWS services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, unauthorized third-party accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Principal: "*" or broad IAM ARNs in the endpoint policy
    • Missing conditions such as aws:sourceVpce or aws:sourceIp
    • Wildcard actions (e.g. s3:*) or resources (arn:aws:s3:::*) in the policy

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Service Access: Attackers can read or write data via the endpoint (e.g., S3, DynamoDB)
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Misuse of the endpoint to steal or corrupt sensitive data
  • Network Bypass: Unintended networks or accounts bypass NAT/firewall controls via the private link
  • Compliance Risks: Violations of least-privilege and network-segmentation mandates

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open S3 Access: An endpoint policy allows any principal to call s3:* on all bucketsan attacker uses it to list and download confidential objects.
  2. Cross-Account DynamoDB Reads: Missing sourceVpce condition lets a third-party account query your DynamoDB tables via the shared endpoint.
  3. IP-Unrestricted Secrets Manager: A wildcard resource policy on the Secrets Manager endpoint lets any VPC host retrieve database credentials, bypassing intended network restrictions.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exfiltration through a broadly configured VPC endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A broadly configured VPC endpointone that allows wide principals, actions, or source networkscan be misused to funnel sensitive data out of your VPC to external or unauthorized recipients.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised instances, and unauthorized third-party accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Endpoint policies with Principal: "*" or missing aws:sourceVpce/sourceIp conditions
    • Overly permissive actions (e.g. s3:GetObject on all buckets)
    • Rogue code on EC2/Lambda using the endpoint to pull and forward data externally

Impacts

  • Unauthorized extraction of confidential data (PII, intellectual property)
  • Bypassing of network egress controls and NAT/firewall restrictions
  • Compliance violations and regulatory penalties

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Data Leak: A compromised EC2 in the VPC uses a wildcard-permitted S3 endpoint to download sensitive objects and uploads them to an external server.
  2. Secrets Extraction: A Lambda with access to the Secrets Manager endpoint pulls all secrets and sends them over HTTPS to an attackers domain.
  3. Cross-Account Exfiltration: An external AWS account assumed a role is allowed by the endpoint policy; it reads your DynamoDB table via the endpoint and exfiltrates the data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Unintended cross-region data flows via improperly placed endpoints
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Improper placement of VPC Endpoints across AWS regions can inadvertently route trafficand thus sensitive datathrough unintended geographic locations, causing cross-region data flows that violate data residency, latency, or compliance requirements.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Misguided administrators, automated deployment scripts, and malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Creating or replicating interface endpoints in the wrong region or account
    • DNS configurations that resolve service names to regional endpoints outside of the intended region
    • Infrastructure-as-code templates that omit region-specific constraints

Impacts

  • Compliance Violations: Data processed or stored in unauthorized jurisdictions breaches regulations (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)
  • Increased Latency & Costs: Traffic detours across regions incur higher network charges and slower response times
  • Data Exposure Risks: Cross-region transfers expand the attack surface and may bypass localized security controls

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Template Misdeploy: A CloudFormation module deploys an S3 VPC Endpoint in us-west-2 instead of us-east-1; application traffic carrying PII traverses to that region, violating data-sovereignty rules.
  2. DNS Override Error: A global DNS record for the Secrets Manager endpoint resolves to a Europe-based VPCE, causing US-only services to fetch secrets through an EU endpoint and exposing them to EU-based monitoring.
  3. Automation Drift: CI/CD pipelines automatically instantiate interface endpoints in every region; a dev team inadvertently routes production database backups through an unintended region, incurring extra egress fees and broader exposure.

threat.name: DNS manipulation redirecting traffic intended for an interface endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
DNS manipulation attacks forged or poisoned DNS responses so that traffic meant for an AWS Interface VPC Endpoint (via its private DNS name) is redirected to attacker-controlled IPs. This subverts AWS PrivateLink security by hijacking service traffic.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised resolvers, or on-premise network attackers
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Poisoning local DNS caches or DHCP-supplied DNS settings to return attacker IPs for the endpoints private DNS name
    • Compromising on-prem DNS servers used in hybrid architectures
    • Exploiting host-level /etc/hosts or resolver overrides on EC2 instances

Impacts

  • Data Interception: Sensitive API traffic (e.g., to S3, KMS, Secrets Manager) is sent to rogue endpoints for eavesdropping.
  • Credential Theft: Stolen tokens or credentials in transit enable further compromise.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate service calls fail or are silently dropped.
  • Regulatory & Compliance Risks: Breach of data-in-transit protections undermines compliance with standards like PCI DSS or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. On-Prem Resolver Poisoning: An attacker plants a false A record in the corporate DNS for secretsmanager.us-east-1.vpce.amazonaws.com, pointing to their server. All on-prem clients push secret-management traffic to the attacker.
  2. EC2 Hosts File Tamper: A malicious process modifies /etc/hosts on EC2 instances so the interface endpoint DNS name resolves to an external IP, diverting traffic and capturing S3 object data.
  3. Hybrid DHCP Hijack: Through rogue DHCP in a branch office, the attacker supplies controlled DNS servers that resolve interface endpoints to attacker nodes, allowing MITM of all PrivateLink calls.

threat.name: Lack of visibility into endpoint usage and potential misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When VPC Endpoint activity isnt logged or monitoredvia VPC Flow Logs, CloudTrail, or GuardDutyusage patterns and malicious behavior (data exfiltration, unauthorized access) can occur without detection, leaving your private link infrastructure blind to threats.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised EC2/Lambda roles, external attackers with network access
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Calling endpoint APIs or services through the endpoint without generating or reviewing logs
    • Abusing overly permissive policies to pass unauthorized traffic
    • Leveraging undetected endpoint tunnels for data exfiltration or command-and-control

Impacts

  • Undetected Misuse: Sensitive data transfers or unauthorized service calls go unnoticed
  • Delayed Incident Response: Lack of alerts on anomalous endpoint patterns prolongs breach dwell time
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to audit endpoint usage violates regulations requiring network monitoring
  • Increased Blast Radius: Unmonitored tunnels facilitate lateral movement within your VPC

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealthy Data Exfiltration: An attacker uses a compromised EC2 role to pull S3 objects via the endpoint; without Flow Logs or CloudTrail entries, the exfiltration isnt detected.
  2. Unauthorized Service Calls: A rogue Lambda function invokes Secrets Manager through a VPC Endpoint; absent GuardDuty alerts on anomalous API calls, the secret retrieval goes unnoticed.
  3. Covert C2 Channel: Malware sets up a DNS-over-HTTPS tunnel through the endpoint to a benign AWS service; without monitoring of endpoint traffic patterns, the command-and-control channel persists undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information

threat.name: Misconfigured security group exposing endpoint ENI to unintended sources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When the security group attached to a VPC Endpoints Elastic Network Interface (ENI) is too permissive or mis-scoped, unintended sourcessuch as the public Internet or off-limits subnetscan reach the endpoint, undermining PrivateLinks isolation guarantees.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised EC2 instances, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Security group rules allowing 0.0.0.0/0 or overly broad CIDRs on the ENIs ports (e.g., TCP 443)
    • Inadvertently reusing a public-facing security group for the endpoint
    • Failure to restrict ingress to the VPCs trusted subnets or specific source VPC Endpoint IDs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Unapproved systems or Internet hosts can call the endpoint and reach the backend service
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Sensitive API calls or data can be intercepted or manipulated
  • Bypass of Network Controls: Firewall, NAT, or proxy protections are circumvented, expanding the attackers lateral movement options
  • Compliance Breaches: Violation of network-segmentation and data-protection requirements

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Internet Reachability: A security group with 0.0.0.0/0 on HTTPS is applied to the endpoint ENI. An external scanner discovers the endpoint and issues requests to S3 via PrivateLink, harvesting confidential objects.
  2. Cross-Subnet Abuse: A QA security group is mistakenly attached to the production endpoint. Hosts in an unrestricted dev subnet exploit it to access production Secrets Manager secrets.
  3. Insider Misconfiguration: A malicious administrator reuses a broad web-tier SG for a new endpoint. An unauthorized application in a different VPC uses the open ingress to invoke internal APIs and exfiltrate data.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Compromised instance within the VPC abusing an endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A compromised EC2 instance or container within your VPC can leverage a VPC Endpoints private connectivity to abuse downstream AWS servicesbypassing Internet gateways and security controlsto exfiltrate data, invoke privileged APIs, or move laterally.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malware-infected or attacker-controlled EC2 instances, compromised ECS/EKS workloads.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Using the endpoints DNS name and IAM role to call services (e.g. S3, Secrets Manager) directly over the private link.
    • Scripted exploitation of overly broad endpoint policies from the compromised host.
    • Automated tools on the instance scanning and abusing any available endpoints in its VPC.

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Stolen objects or secrets are pulled via the endpoint and forwarded externally.
  • Privilege Escalation: The instance invokes sensitive APIs (e.g. IAM, KMS) to expand access.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromise spreads to other services or accounts accessible through the endpoint.
  • Audit Blindness: Private-link activity may bypass perimeter monitoring, delaying detection.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Secrets Harvest: An attackers backdoor on an EC2 uses the VPC Endpoint for Secrets Manager to retrieve database credentials, then uploads them to an external server.
  2. S3 Data Leak: A compromised container scripts aws s3 sync over the S3 VPC Endpoint, mirroring sensitive data to attacker-controlled storage.
  3. IAM Role Abuse: Malware on an instance exploits its attached role via the endpoint to call sts:AssumeRole on a higher-privilege cross-account role, pivoting across your AWS environment.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Control traffic using network ACLs
countermeasure.desc: Manage inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level by configuring network Access Control Lists (ACLs) in your VPC. Network ACLs act as stateless firewalls for your subnets, allowing you to set rules that permit or deny traffic based on IP protocol, port number, and source/destination IP address. To implement this, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, create or modify network ACLs, and associate them with the appropriate subnets. Regularly review and update ACL rules to enhance security and compliance.

countermeasure.name: Detect potential threats with Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Enable Amazon GuardDuty to continuously monitor VPC flow logs for malicious activity and potential security threats. GuardDuty uses machine learning and threat intelligence to analyze traffic patterns and detect anomalies. To implement this, activate GuardDuty in the AWS Management Console, configure it to ingest VPC flow logs, DNS logs, and CloudTrail event logs. Regularly review GuardDuty findings and take appropriate actions to mitigate identified threats, ensuring your VPC remains secure against evolving attack vectors.

countermeasure.name: Distribute subnets across multiple availability zones
countermeasure.desc: To ensure high availability, fault tolerance, and scalability of your applications hosted on Amazon VPC, create subnets in multiple Availability Zones (AZs) within the same AWS Region. An Availability Zone comprises one or more data centers with independent power, networking, and connectivity. By distributing subnets across multiple AZs, you can mitigate the risk of a single point of failure and enhance the resilience of your application against potential outages or failures in a single AZ. This approach provides redundancy and improves overall system reliability.

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs
countermeasure.desc: Implement VPC flow logs to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces within your VPC. This log data can help you monitor network traffic, identify potential security threats, diagnose network issues, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. To enable VPC Flow Logs, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, select your VPC, and create a new Flow Log, specifying the destination for the log data, such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs or an S3 bucket. Regularly review and analyze these logs for abnormal traffic patterns and security incidents.

To implement, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, configure the Network Access Analyzer by defining the scope and criteria for access analysis, and run assessments regularly. Review findings to address any unintended access, ensuring robust network security.

AWS Network Firewall provides stateful, managed network firewall and intrusion prevention services to safeguard your VPC from malicious activity. To implement it, create a firewall in the AWS Management Console, configure rules to control inbound and outbound traffic, and associate the firewall with your VPC subnets. Regularly update and monitor these rules to ensure they align with your security policies and threat landscape.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single point of failure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A Single Point of Failure (SPOF) refers to a critical component or node within a system whose failure can cause the entire system to stop functioning. In a cloud environment like Amazon VPS, this can result from configuring all resources within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leading to potential outages if that zone experiences issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Natural disasters affecting a specific AZ.
  • Technical failures such as power outages, network issues, or hardware malfunctions within the AZ.
  • Cyberattacks targeting the infrastructure of a specific AZ.

Impacts

  • Downtime and service disruptions.
  • Loss of availability for applications and services.
  • Potential data loss or corruption.
  • Financial losses due to service outages and recovery costs.
  • Reputational damage due to service unreliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Natural Disaster: A severe storm impacts the data center in a single AZ, causing all services hosted in that zone to become unavailable.
  2. Technical Failure: A power outage in the data center leads to downtime for all resources configured solely in that AZ.
  3. Cyberattack: A targeted DDoS attack overwhelms the infrastructure of a single AZ, resulting in service disruption for all resources within that zone.

To mitigate this threat, it is recommended to distribute resources across multiple Availability Zones, ensuring redundancy and high availability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized network access occurs when individuals or entities gain access to a network without permission, potentially leading to data breaches, service disruption, and exploitation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers using methods such as brute force or exploitation of vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors exploiting legitimate access.
  • Misconfigurations in security settings, such as overly permissive security groups or network ACLs.

Impacts

  • Data theft and loss of sensitive information.
  • Service disruptions and potential downtime.
  • Increased risk of further network and system exploitation.
  • Financial losses and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: A hacker gains unauthorized access to an EC2 instance by exploiting a vulnerability in a web application and subsequently accessing the underlying network.
  2. Internal Misuse: An employee uses their legitimate access to explore unauthorized network segments, leading to potential data exfiltration.
  3. Misconfiguration: A misconfigured security group allows inbound traffic from any IP address, enabling an attacker to exploit services running within the VPC.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strict access controls using security groups and network ACLs, regularly review and update security configurations, and employ network monitoring tools to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts promptly.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient monitoring refers to the lack of adequate surveillance and tracking mechanisms to detect, log, and analyze activities within a system. In Amazon VPS, this can lead to undetected security incidents, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Hackers exploiting unmonitored vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors taking advantage of weak logging practices.
  • Unintended configuration changes going unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Delayed or missed detection of security breaches.
  • Increased risk of data theft or corruption.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
  • Prolonged downtime and extended incident response times.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Data Breach: A hacker gains unauthorized access to a VPS due to a missed security patch, which goes unnoticed due to insufficient monitoring.
  2. Internal Threat: An employee with elevated privileges accesses sensitive data without proper logging, making it difficult to trace the action.
  3. Configuration Error: Misconfigurations in security groups or network ACLs are not detected, leading to potential exposure of resources.

To address this threat, it is crucial to implement comprehensive monitoring solutions like AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail, and to regularly review and analyze logs to identify and respond to potential security incidents promptly.

threat.name: Unintended network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unintended network access occurs when resources within a network are inadvertently exposed to unauthorized entities due to misconfigurations or oversight, leading to potential data breaches, unauthorized modifications, and service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting exposed services.
  • Internal users accessing unintended resources due to misconfigured permissions.
  • Automated scripts or tools scanning for open ports and services.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Service disruptions and operational inefficiencies.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation and lateral movement within the network.
  • Financial and reputational damage due to data breaches and service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exposed Services: A database is unintentionally left accessible from the internet due to misconfigured security groups, allowing an attacker to access and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  2. Internal Access: An employee accesses confidential files stored in an improperly secured S3 bucket that should have been restricted.
  3. Automated Scans: An automated tool finds an open management port on an EC2 instance, which is then exploited to gain unauthorized access.

To mitigate this threat, regularly review and update security group rules, network ACLs, and use tools like AWS Network Access Analyzer to identify and rectify unintended network exposures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Unfiltered traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unfiltered traffic refers to network traffic that is not adequately controlled or monitored, allowing potentially harmful data to enter or exit the network unchecked. This can lead to security vulnerabilities, data breaches, and network inefficiencies in an Amazon VPS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers sending malicious data packets.
  • Internal users inadvertently or deliberately bypassing security measures.
  • Misconfigured security groups and network ACLs allowing all traffic.

Impacts

  • Exposure to malware and other malicious content.
  • Data exfiltration or loss of sensitive information.
  • Network congestion and reduced performance.
  • Increased risk of further network exploitation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malware Infiltration: An attacker sends malicious traffic that goes unchecked into the network, infecting servers and spreading malware.
  2. Data Exfiltration: An internal user sends sensitive data out of the network due to lack of outbound traffic filtering.
  3. DoS Attack: Unfiltered inbound traffic leads to a Denial of Service attack, overwhelming the network and causing service outages.

To mitigate this threat, implement and regularly update security groups, network ACLs, and use AWS Network Firewall to filter and monitor inbound and outbound traffic.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised IAM credentials
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Compromised IAM (Identity and Access Management) credentials refer to instances where attackers gain unauthorized access to AWS resources by obtaining valid IAM credentials. This can lead to significant security breaches, unauthorized data access, and control over AWS services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Phishing attacks to trick users into revealing credentials.
  • Brute force attacks to guess passwords.
  • Exploitation of weak password policies.
  • Insider threats where employees misuse access privileges.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Potential data breaches and data loss.
  • Unauthorized modifications or deletions of resources.
  • Financial losses due to misuse of AWS services.
  • Reputational damage from security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phishing Attack: An attacker sends a phishing email to an employee, tricking them into providing their IAM credentials, which are then used to access and extract data from S3 buckets.
  2. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt logins until they successfully guess a weak password, gaining unauthorized access to critical resources.
  3. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their IAM credentials to access sensitive information and leak it to external parties.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strong password policies, enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all IAM users, regularly rotate credentials, and monitor IAM activities using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config for unusual access patterns.

weakness.name: CWE-203
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-203: Observable Discrepancy The product behaves differently or sends different responses under different circumstances in a way that is observable to an unauthorized actor, which exposes security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not. Discrepancies can take many forms, and variations may be detectable in timing, control flow, communications such as replies or requests, or general behavior. These discrepancies can reveal information about the product's operation or internal state to an unauthorized actor. In some cases, discrepancies can be used by attackers to form a side channel.

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300 CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities. CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-453 CWE-77 CWE-502
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-453: Insecure Default Variable Initialization The product, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.
CWE-77: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection') The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.
CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Comprehensive encryption and secure configuration
countermeasure.desc:
Select Encryption Algorithms:

  • Choose secure encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256 for symmetric encryption or RSA-2048 for asymmetric encryption).
  • Validate that the selected algorithms are compliant with industry standards like NIST or FIPS.

Implement Encryption for Data in Transit:

  • Configure TLS (Transport Layer Security) using a secure version (TLS 1.2 or higher) for data transmitted between clients and servers.
  • Use a strong cipher suite (e.g., ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384).
  • Verify server certificates to prevent Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Apply disk encryption or file-level encryption to protect sensitive data stored on servers or client devices.
  • Utilize a key management system (KMS) to securely store encryption keys.

Enable Authentication and Authorization:

  • Implement mutual TLS (mTLS) to authenticate both clients and servers.
  • Use role-based access control (RBAC) or attribute-based access control (ABAC) to enforce strict authorization policies.

Disable Insecure Protocols:

  • Ensure that outdated and insecure protocols (e.g., SSLv3, TLS 1.0) are disabled.
  • Block known vulnerable ciphers like RC4, DES, and NULL.

Configure Security Headers:

  • Add HTTP headers such as Strict-Transport-Security to enforce HTTPS.
  • Use Content-Security-Policy to mitigate cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

Conduct Security Testing:

  • Perform regular vulnerability scans and penetration tests to identify weaknesses.
  • Monitor encryption logs for any anomalies or signs of compromise.

Educate the Team:

  • Train development and IT teams on encryption standards and secure configuration practices.
  • Maintain up-to-date documentation for reference.

Stay Updated:

  • Keep encryption libraries and frameworks up-to-date to address known vulnerabilities.
  • Subscribe to security advisories for prompt awareness of emerging threats.

Incorporate these steps to build a robust security posture for the connection security component, following best practices from organizations like OWASP and NIST.

reference.name: Comprehensive Guide to TLS Encryption Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Enforce least privilege and segregation of duties
countermeasure.desc:
Identify Roles and Permissions:

  • Create a detailed list of user roles and the permissions each role requires to perform its tasks.
  • Map permissions to roles based on functional requirements, ensuring they align with business needs.

Define Privilege Boundaries:

  • Restrict each role to only the minimum necessary permissions required for its responsibilities.
  • Apply read-only access where write or execute permissions aren't needed.

Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Utilize RBAC to assign permissions based on defined roles instead of individual users.
  • Ensure that roles do not overlap unnecessarily and that sensitive operations are assigned to distinct roles.

Apply Segregation of Duties:

  • Separate conflicting roles to prevent a single user from having comprehensive control over a process (e.g., avoid giving a developer the ability to deploy to production without oversight).
  • Implement approval workflows or peer reviews for sensitive operations.

Review and Update Access Regularly:

  • Conduct periodic audits of user roles and permissions to identify and remove excessive privileges.
  • Ensure that permissions are updated promptly when roles or personnel change.

Monitor Access Logs:

  • Enable logging for access to sensitive operations and resources.
  • Review logs regularly to detect unusual or unauthorized access patterns.

Educate and Train Staff:

  • Provide training to team members on the principles of least privilege and segregation of duties.
  • Encourage staff to report any discrepancies or violations in access control.

Establish Security Policies:

  • Document and enforce company-wide policies for least privilege and segregation of duties.
  • Include these principles in the onboarding process for new hires.

Use Automation:

  • Implement automated tools for managing roles, permissions, and audits to reduce human error.
  • Automate alerts to identify permission violations or critical changes in real-time.

Incorporating these steps will help secure your system by ensuring each user has access only to the resources they need while preventing conflicts of interest. Follow guidelines from ISO/IEC 27001 or NIST SP 800-53 for industry-standard practices.

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive DoS protection strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Network-Based Filtering:

  • Implement network firewalls or Web Application Firewalls (WAF) to identify and filter out malicious traffic at the network edge.
  • Use geo-blocking or IP whitelisting to limit traffic from regions where you don't expect legitimate users.

Rate Limiting and Throttling:

  • Apply rate limiting to APIs, web services, and login attempts to prevent overwhelming requests from any single source.
  • Enforce connection throttling to block or delay further requests from sources exceeding reasonable usage thresholds.

Traffic Anomaly Detection:

  • Deploy Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) or Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) to detect unusual traffic patterns that could signal an attack.
  • Use machine learning models to identify traffic anomalies and dynamically update blocking rules.

Redundancy and Load Balancing:

  • Distribute traffic across multiple servers using load balancers to mitigate single points of failure.
  • Establish a content delivery network (CDN) to cache resources and distribute them globally, reducing the impact on your core infrastructure.

Scaling Infrastructure:

  • Use cloud-based auto-scaling solutions to handle unexpected traffic surges.
  • Have standby capacity available that can be activated quickly during an attack.

Resource Prioritization:

  • Prioritize essential services, limiting resource access for non-critical functionalities during an attack.
  • Gracefully degrade non-essential services to focus on core business operations.

Application-Level Protections:

  • Implement CAPTCHA or other human verification methods to differentiate between legitimate users and bots.
  • Validate all incoming inputs to prevent the exploitation of vulnerabilities.

Monitoring and Alerts:

  • Monitor traffic continuously and set up alerts for significant traffic spikes or error rates.
  • Implement a SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) system for centralized monitoring and analysis.

Incident Response Plan:

  • Develop a comprehensive incident response plan detailing roles and procedures to follow during an attack.
  • Test the plan periodically with simulated DoS scenarios to improve preparedness.

Collaboration with ISPs:

  • Coordinate with your Internet Service Provider (ISP) to monitor and block large-scale attacks at the ISP level.
  • Consider subscribing to a third-party DDoS protection service for emergency response and traffic diversion.

These steps form a multi-layered defense strategy to reduce your system's vulnerability to DoS attacks and ensure resilient, continuous service availability. Follow NIST SP 800-44 or the OWASP guidelines for best practices.

reference.name: CIS Controls for Effective Cyber Defense
OWASP Guide to Denial of Service Attacks

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive security configuration and validation framework
countermeasure.desc:
Establish Configuration Baselines:

  • Define security baseline configurations for each environment (development, testing, staging, production).
  • Ensure configurations align with industry standards like CIS Benchmarks or NIST guidelines.

Define Security Policies:

  • Document policies for firewalls, encryption, logging, access control, and application hardening.
  • Align policies with compliance requirements (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) and organizational risk management goals.

Automate Configuration Management:

  • Use Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools (e.g., Ansible, Terraform, Chef) to manage and enforce security configurations.
  • Maintain configuration files in a version-controlled repository for auditability.

Implement Validation Tools:

  • Integrate automated security scanners (e.g., OpenSCAP, Lynis) to assess compliance with baseline configurations.
  • Utilize application-specific security tools like OWASP Dependency-Check for third-party dependencies.

Apply Continuous Monitoring:

  • Deploy configuration monitoring tools to detect and alert on deviations from the established baseline.
  • Monitor key configurations (e.g., firewall rules, access permissions, encryption settings) for unauthorized changes.

Perform Regular Audits:

  • Schedule regular security audits to verify adherence to baseline configurations.
  • Involve external security experts periodically for unbiased reviews and vulnerability assessments.

Develop a Remediation Plan:

  • Establish a clear remediation plan for restoring secure configurations when deviations are detected.
  • Automate the remediation process for frequently recurring configuration issues.

Update and Refine Configurations:

  • Review security configurations after each significant software update or architectural change.
  • Update the baseline configurations to reflect emerging threats and new security standards.

Document Configuration Changes:

  • Maintain a change log documenting each modification made to security configurations.
  • Include justification, impact assessment, and responsible personnel for each change.

Educate and Train Teams:

  • Conduct training sessions for development, operations, and security teams on the importance of secure configurations.
  • Provide documentation and access to relevant tools to enable teams to perform their roles effectively.

By following these steps, you'll establish a robust security configuration framework that continuously enforces and validates security policies, ensuring compliance and reducing vulnerabilities across your infrastructure.

reference.name: Comprehensive Guide to Configuration and Validation Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Implement cryptographic best practices
countermeasure.desc:
Choose Strong Algorithms and Key Sizes:

  • Use current, standardized encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256 for symmetric encryption, RSA-2048 or ECC with P-256 for asymmetric encryption).
  • Avoid deprecated algorithms like MD5, SHA-1, DES, and RC4.

Utilize Secure Key Management:

  • Store encryption keys securely using a Hardware Security Module (HSM) or a cloud key management service.
  • Implement access controls for key management systems, ensuring only authorized personnel can retrieve encryption keys.

Use Unique Keys and Initialization Vectors (IVs):

  • Ensure that each encryption session generates unique keys or initialization vectors to prevent replay attacks.
  • For symmetric encryption, use a different encryption key per data segment or message whenever possible.

Implement Strong Authentication Mechanisms:

  • Apply cryptographic hash functions (e.g., SHA-256) with a salt to passwords or sensitive data.
  • Use HMAC (Hashed Message Authentication Code) to verify message integrity.

Secure Data in Transit:

  • Enable TLS (Transport Layer Security) version 1.2 or higher for data transmissions.
  • Use strong cipher suites (e.g., ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384) and disable vulnerable protocols (e.g., SSL, TLS 1.0).

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Apply full-disk encryption or file-level encryption for sensitive data stored in databases, backups, or logs.
  • Enable transparent encryption features offered by databases or storage systems.

Handle Key Rotation and Expiry:

  • Set policies for regular key rotation to minimize risks from long-lived encryption keys.
  • Automate key rotation processes where possible to reduce manual intervention errors.

Implement Digital Signatures:

  • Apply digital signatures for critical data or documents to ensure authenticity and non-repudiation.
  • Use appropriate asymmetric algorithms and secure private key storage.

Regularly Audit and Update Libraries:

  • Monitor cryptographic libraries for vulnerabilities and update them promptly to the latest secure versions.
  • Conduct regular code reviews to ensure secure cryptographic usage.

Educate Development Teams:

  • Train developers on secure cryptographic principles and library usage.
  • Provide reference guidelines or code snippets for integrating cryptography into applications securely.

Implementing these cryptographic best practices will help you safeguard sensitive data against unauthorized access and integrity breaches. Stay informed about emerging cryptographic threats and standards from trusted organizations like NIST or OWASP.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Implement secure error handling practices
countermeasure.desc:
Define General Error Handling Policies:

  • Establish policies that clearly outline acceptable behaviors for error messages and logging.
  • Ensure that policies prohibit the display of sensitive data in error messages.

Standardize Error Messages:

  • Create standardized, user-friendly error messages that provide only necessary information (e.g., "An error occurred. Please try again or contact support.").
  • Avoid exposing sensitive details like stack traces, file paths, or database information.

Log Errors Securely:

  • Log detailed error information for internal use only and store logs in a secure location with strict access controls.
  • Use a centralized logging system to aggregate logs and apply encryption for sensitive log data.

Categorize and Prioritize Errors:

  • Classify errors by severity to prioritize response efforts (e.g., fatal errors, non-fatal errors, warnings).
  • Implement alerts for critical errors that may indicate security vulnerabilities.

Apply Input Validation:

  • Ensure all inputs are properly sanitized to prevent unexpected errors from malicious input (e.g., SQL injection, XSS).
  • Implement validation checks both client-side and server-side.

Graceful Error Recovery:

  • Design applications to handle errors gracefully without exposing internal mechanisms or causing service disruptions.
  • For transient errors, retry the operation up to a predefined limit, then log and alert if persistent.

Test Error Handling Mechanisms:

  • Conduct penetration tests and fuzz testing to identify unhandled exceptions.
  • Simulate error scenarios in test environments to confirm proper handling and user messaging.

Protect Against Denial of Service:

  • Limit the impact of potential Denial of Service (DoS) attacks by rate-limiting operations that could trigger excessive errors.
  • Use circuit breakers to detect and isolate repeated errors in service-oriented architectures.

Educate Developers:

  • Train developers on secure coding practices related to error handling, emphasizing the importance of masking sensitive data.
  • Provide secure error handling code samples and guidelines for common use cases.

Review and Improve:

  • Review error handling strategies periodically to address emerging threats and application changes.
  • Refine logging and alert mechanisms based on past incidents and new insights.

By following these practices, you'll establish a secure error handling framework that protects sensitive information while providing useful feedback for both users and internal teams.

countermeasure.name: Secure logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Establish Log Retention Policies:

  • Define policies that specify which logs are required, the data they should contain, and the retention duration.
  • Ensure retention complies with regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) and internal guidelines.

Limit Sensitive Data Logging:

  • Avoid logging sensitive data such as passwords, personally identifiable information (PII), or financial details.
  • Mask or anonymize sensitive information if it must be logged for troubleshooting purposes.

Apply Access Controls:

  • Restrict access to logs to authorized personnel only, using role-based access control (RBAC) or attribute-based access control (ABAC).
  • Implement encryption for log files, both in transit and at rest, to protect against unauthorized access.

Log Key Security Events:

  • Ensure critical events like login attempts, privilege escalations, data modifications, and configuration changes are logged.
  • Log administrative activities, such as access to key systems and deployment of critical applications.

Centralize Logging Infrastructure:

  • Use a centralized logging platform (e.g., ELK stack, Splunk) to collect and manage logs from various sources.
  • Ensure that logs are ingested in near real-time and appropriately indexed for efficient querying.

Enable Time Synchronization:

  • Configure time synchronization (e.g., via NTP) across all systems to ensure consistent timestamps in logs.
  • This consistency is crucial for correlating events and reconstructing incident timelines.

Monitor Logs Continuously:

  • Set up automated monitoring rules to detect suspicious patterns like repeated login failures, unusual traffic spikes, or privilege misuse.
  • Implement alerts to notify relevant personnel of high-severity incidents.

Regularly Review Logs:

  • Conduct periodic log reviews to identify missed security events, anomalies, or policy violations.
  • Use data analytics to identify long-term patterns and optimize security controls.

Integrate with Security Systems:

  • Integrate logging infrastructure with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools for comprehensive threat detection.
  • Correlate log data with threat intelligence feeds to identify known attack patterns.

Educate and Train Staff:

  • Provide training on secure logging practices, emphasizing the importance of log integrity and monitoring.
  • Regularly update the team on new logging guidelines or threats requiring attention.

Implement these secure logging and monitoring practices to maintain strong visibility into your system activities, helping you detect and respond to security incidents efficiently.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Computer Security Log Management

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of Service and resource exhaustion
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Denial of Service (DoS) and Resource Exhaustion attacks are attempts to make a system or network resource unavailable to its intended users by overwhelming it with a flood of illegitimate traffic, requests, or resource consumption. In the context of connection security, such attacks focus on exhausting system resources, like memory, CPU, or bandwidth, rendering services unresponsive or completely unavailable.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Individuals or groups aiming to disrupt services for financial gain, revenge, or activism.
  • Botnets: Networks of compromised devices used to amplify attack traffic (Distributed Denial of Service - DDoS).
  • Malicious Insiders: Employees or partners with privileged access, able to exploit internal network resources.
  • Automated Tools: Scripts or malware designed to flood services with requests or exploit known vulnerabilities.
  • Traffic Amplification: Abuse of open resolvers and misconfigured services to amplify traffic (e.g., DNS amplification).

Impacts

  • Service Unavailability: Legitimate users cannot access the affected services.
  • Financial Losses: Revenue loss due to service downtime, customer churn, and SLA penalties.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust due to perceived inability to secure services.
  • Operational Disruption: Impact on internal operations, emergency responses, and incident handling.
  • Resource Depletion: Overload of CPU, memory, network bandwidth, and database connections.

Example Attack Scenarios

SYN Flood Attack

  • Attackers send numerous TCP SYN packets without completing the handshake, filling up the server's connection queue and preventing new connections.

Application Layer DoS

  • Attackers send a high number of HTTP requests to an API endpoint that triggers resource-intensive processing, causing high server CPU usage and unresponsiveness.

DNS Amplification

  • Attackers send DNS queries with spoofed source IPs (victim's address) to misconfigured DNS resolvers, leading to large responses directed at the victim.

Slowloris Attack

  • Attackers open many slow connections to the server, never completing them, gradually filling the server's connection limit and denying new connections.

Botnet-Based DDoS

  • A botnet controlled by an attacker generates enormous traffic (HTTP requests, UDP packets) aimed at overwhelming the victim's bandwidth and server resources.

Proactively addressing these threats requires implementing network, server, and application-level defenses, in addition to monitoring and rapid incident response mechanisms.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Elevation of privilege through connection misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Elevation of privilege through connection misconfiguration involves attackers exploiting weaknesses in network or system configurations to gain unauthorized access or elevated privileges. This often occurs when connections to sensitive systems are not properly secured, allowing attackers to bypass security restrictions or intercept traffic.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: External actors who exploit insecure public-facing services, APIs, or networking equipment.
  • Malicious Insiders: Employees or partners with internal access who misuse their privileges to exploit misconfigured connections.
  • Automated Tools: Tools that scan for open ports, insecure services, or vulnerabilities in network configurations.
  • Spoofing and Man-in-the-Middle (MitM): Techniques that leverage weak or misconfigured connections to intercept or alter communication.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive data or systems that they shouldn't have permissions for.
  • Privilege Escalation: Attackers gain higher-level permissions, enabling them to control critical services or perform administrative actions.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data is extracted, causing potential regulatory breaches and financial or reputational damage.
  • System Compromise: Attackers may gain control over key network components or applications, potentially leading to denial-of-service or further exploitation.

Example Attack Scenarios

Insecure Database Connections:

  • Databases configured with weak authentication mechanisms or exposed to the internet allow attackers to access, modify, or delete sensitive information.

Open Management Ports:

  • Unrestricted or misconfigured management ports on network devices (e.g., SSH, RDP, Telnet) allow attackers to perform administrative functions if accessed.

Improper Network Segmentation

  • Inadequate separation between user networks and administrative networks enables attackers to pivot from a compromised user account to administrative systems.

Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attack

  • An attacker intercepts unsecured communications between clients and servers, potentially manipulating or capturing sensitive data if encryption is not enforced.

Weak API Security

  • APIs lacking proper authentication and authorization checks allow attackers to invoke privileged functions or access sensitive data.

Preventing elevation of privilege through connection misconfiguration requires secure configuration practices, network segmentation, monitoring, and regular security assessments of network and system configurations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of improperly secured system configurations and the handling of input data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers can exploit improperly secured system configurations and the mishandling of input data in connection security software to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, or disrupt operations. Improper security configurations might include weak access controls, default or no encryption, and unpatched vulnerabilities. Poorly sanitized or unchecked input data can lead to injection attacks or denial-of-service attacks. The cumulative impact of these flaws is that they can serve as an entry point for malicious actors to compromise the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Threat Agents: Hackers, criminal organizations, and state-sponsored actors aiming to compromise the system through known vulnerabilities or default configurations.
  • Internal Threat Agents: Malicious insiders exploiting trusted access to alter configurations or inject harmful data.
  • Attack Vectors
    • Exploiting weak default settings, lack of encryption, or improperly configured security rules.
    • Injecting malformed input data via web interfaces, APIs, or other communication protocols.
    • Phishing, social engineering, or other tactics to trick users into submitting malicious input.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Data breaches exposing sensitive user or company information.
  • Integrity: Data manipulation causing unauthorized changes in critical records.
  • Availability: System downtime or service unavailability due to disrupted or disabled services.
  • Reputation: Loss of trust, legal consequences, and diminished brand value.

Example Attack Scenarios

SQL Injection via Web Application

An attacker sends malicious SQL commands through improperly sanitized input fields in a web application. The commands modify database entries or extract sensitive information, compromising data integrity and confidentiality.

Configuration Exploitation

An administrator leaves the default username and password unchanged for a network appliance. An attacker scans the network for devices using these credentials, gaining access and altering network routing rules.

Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Attack

A malicious user injects a script into a web application's input form. The script runs in another user's browser when they access that page, potentially stealing cookies or performing actions on behalf of that user.

Phishing Attack with Malicious Payloads

Employees receive an email posing as a company alert, containing a malicious attachment. Once opened, the attachment exploits a system vulnerability, providing attackers access to sensitive resources.

Proper security configuration and validation of input data are critical to mitigating these threats, requiring periodic audits, secure coding practices, and updated security policies.

threat.name: Securing communication channels to prevent unauthorized access and data exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Securing communication channels is a vital step in preventing unauthorized access and protecting data from exposure. Heres a comprehensive approach:

1. Encryption

  • Transport Layer Security (TLS): Utilize TLS to encrypt data during transmission between client and server. Ensure certificates are properly managed and up-to-date.
  • End-to-End Encryption: Implement end-to-end encryption for messaging systems to protect data from any intermediary entities.

2. Authentication and Authorization

  • Mutual Authentication: Both parties should authenticate each other before initiating communication, using certificates or other cryptographic means.
  • API Authentication: For APIs, use tokens, OAuth, or API keys to validate legitimate clients.

3. Secure Configuration

  • Secure Protocols: Disable outdated protocols like SSL, TLS 1.0/1.1, or older cipher suites that are considered weak.
  • Configuration Hardening: Regularly review and harden configurations to avoid vulnerabilities like default credentials or weak access rules.

4. Monitoring and Auditing

  • Network Traffic Monitoring: Monitor network traffic to detect and alert on suspicious patterns that could indicate an attack.
  • Logging: Maintain detailed logs of authentication, authorization attempts, and other relevant activity to aid in incident investigation.

5. Input Validation

  • Sanitization: Implement input validation to filter out malicious content like SQL injection payloads, cross-site scripting, or buffer overflows.
  • Secure APIs: Design APIs to accept only sanitized, validated inputs to avoid exploitation.

6. Patch Management

  • Regular Updates: Keep systems and libraries updated with security patches to prevent attackers from exploiting known vulnerabilities.
  • Dependency Management: Monitor third-party software dependencies for vulnerabilities and patch them promptly.

7. User Education and Awareness

  • Phishing and Social Engineering: Train employees to recognize and avoid phishing attacks or social engineering attempts that could lead to unauthorized access.
  • Credential Management: Encourage the use of strong passwords and secure storage of authentication credentials.

8. Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

  • Access Control: Enforce MFA for all sensitive communication channels to add an extra layer of security.

Implementing these strategies helps ensure that communication channels are properly secured, reducing the risk of unauthorized access and data exposure.

reference.name: OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet

threat.name: Inadequate error handling exposing sensitive information
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate error handling occurs when systems fail to sanitize or suppress error messages, leading to the unintended exposure of sensitive information. This often results in the disclosure of internal implementation details, system configurations, database structures, or user data that attackers can exploit to facilitate further attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals or hackers seeking to understand system behavior, configurations, or weaknesses through overly verbose error messages.
  • Malicious Insiders: Employees with limited access privileges exploiting error messages to expand their access scope.
  • Automated Tools: Scanning tools that identify vulnerable applications through predictable error responses and known message patterns.

Impacts

  • Information Disclosure: Exposure of sensitive data such as credentials, personally identifiable information (PII), or server architecture details.
  • Further Exploitation: Attackers leverage the exposed information to exploit weaknesses, find misconfigurations, or craft targeted attacks.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust due to the mishandling of sensitive information.

Example Attack Scenarios

Database Error Messages

  • SQL errors, unfiltered from web applications, reveal details about database schema, structure, and even data content, enabling SQL injection attacks.

Authentication Error Details

  • Overly detailed authentication error messages ("User not found" vs. "Incorrect password") allow attackers to verify if a username exists, facilitating brute force attacks.

File System Exposure

  • File inclusion errors that reveal file paths can lead to directory traversal attacks or help identify sensitive files to target directly.

Server Configuration Details

  • Web server error messages (e.g., 500 Internal Server Error) sometimes expose software versions or configuration details, revealing potential vulnerabilities to attackers.

Stack Trace Disclosure

  • Web applications display detailed stack traces that expose internal function names, code structures, and programming errors, helping attackers map the applications logic.

Mitigating this threat requires developers to adopt secure error-handling practices, which include sanitizing error messages, logging internal details securely, and providing user-friendly but generic feedback on errors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1087 - Account Discovery||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information

threat.name: Side-channel attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Side-channel attacks exploit unintended channels of information leakage to infer sensitive data. Instead of directly attacking the cryptographic algorithms, attackers analyze observable characteristics, such as timing, power consumption, or electromagnetic emissions, to reveal information that should be protected. These attacks are particularly effective against cryptographic implementations, authentication processes, and hardware devices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals capable of accessing hardware components or collecting and analyzing observable data over the network.
  • Malicious Insiders: Insiders with privileged access to devices or systems can gather side-channel information to undermine cryptographic keys.
  • State-Sponsored Groups: Advanced threat actors who can invest significant resources into data collection and analysis.
  • Automated Tools: Tools capable of identifying timing discrepancies, electromagnetic patterns, or power usage irregularities.

Impacts

  • Key Leakage: Cryptographic keys may be exposed through subtle timing variations, electromagnetic emissions, or power usage differences.
  • Authentication Bypass: Authentication tokens or passwords may be compromised if attackers can deduce patterns from observable data.
  • Sensitive Data Exposure: Private information (e.g., encryption keys, session tokens) is disclosed if attackers can infer values from unintentional leaks.
  • System Compromise: Attackers gain unauthorized access to systems through compromised keys or credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios

Timing Attacks on Cryptography

  • Subtle timing differences during cryptographic operations reveal specific data, allowing attackers to infer private keys.

Electromagnetic Emissions

  • Attackers capture and analyze electromagnetic emissions from devices performing cryptographic operations to recover secret keys.

Power Analysis

  • Differential Power Analysis (DPA) uses variations in power consumption during cryptographic processing to deduce secret keys.

Cache Timing Attacks

  • Variations in cache timing reveal sensitive data, often in multi-tenant environments where an attacker shares the same hardware.

Acoustic Analysis

  • Attackers analyze acoustic signals (e.g., keyboard clicks) to deduce typed passwords.

Mitigating side-channel attacks requires implementing secure cryptographic libraries, constant-time algorithms, shielding for hardware devices, and careful monitoring of unexpected emissions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1005 - Data from Local System||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1114.001 - Local Email Collection||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Repudiation of actions over connections
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Repudiation refers to the denial of an action or event by an entity involved in a transaction or interaction. In communication networks, this could involve a user or system denying responsibility for an action taken over a connection. This can be problematic when tracing the origin of data or resolving disputes over compromised actions.

Mitigating the Risk of Repudiation

Logging and Monitoring

  • Comprehensive Logging: Ensure that all significant events are recorded in secure logs. Capture sufficient details such as timestamps, user IDs, IP addresses, and action descriptions.
  • Immutable Logs: Implement tamper-proof logging solutions to ensure that logs cannot be altered without detection.

Digital Signatures

  • Non-Repudiation Mechanism: Utilize digital signatures for sensitive transactions to provide proof that an action was taken by a specific entity.
  • Public Key Infrastructure (PKI): A PKI framework can ensure the validity of digital signatures by managing certificates and revocations.

Authentication and Access Control

  • Strong Authentication: Use multi-factor authentication to verify users' identities before they can perform significant actions.
  • Authorization Policies: Implement strict role-based access controls to limit users' actions based on their roles.

Audit Trails

  • Detailed Audit Logs: Maintain a detailed history of actions and changes within critical systems to help verify which entity performed a particular action.
  • Periodic Audits: Regular audits help identify any discrepancies or unauthorized actions that may have gone unnoticed.

Data Integrity

  • Checksums and Hashes: Use cryptographic checksums or hashes to verify the integrity of transmitted data. Any alterations can thus be detected.
  • Encryption: Protect data in transit and at rest to prevent tampering.

User Awareness

  • Training: Educate users on the importance of accountability and their role in preventing repudiation.
  • Responsibility: Make sure users understand that their credentials should not be shared or left vulnerable.

Incident Response

  • Forensic Analysis: In case of disputes, a robust forensic analysis process can trace actions to specific users or systems.
  • Legal Preparedness: Prepare legal documentation or contracts that define and attribute responsibilities to specific parties.

These measures create a system where the actions performed over connections are accountable, identifiable, and traceable, minimizing repudiation and ensuring accurate dispute resolution.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectconnections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsthrough vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?
  • What Is AWS Config?

countermeasure.name: Enforce IAM identity-based policies for AWS Direct Connect
countermeasure.desc:
Create narrowly scoped IAM policies (and, if you use AWS Organizations, complementary SCPs) so that only approved network-admin roles can perform Direct Connect management actionssuch as CreateConnection, AllocateHostedConnection, ConfirmPrivateVirtualInterface, or DeleteLag.

  • Author purpose-built roles give each network-engineering or automation role a custom policy that allows only the Direct Connect APIs it truly needs and only in approved Regions or on resources tagged Environment=prod. Example snippet:
  • {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": [
       "directconnect:CreateConnection",
       "directconnect:DeleteConnection",
       "directconnect:Describe*"
     ],
     "Resource": "*",
     "Condition": {
       "StringEquals": { "aws:RequestedRegion": [ "us-east-1", "eu-west-1" ] },
       "ForAllValues:StringEquals": { "aws:ResourceTag/NetworkOwner": "net-ops" }
     }
    }
  • Block everyone else attach an SCP that denies directconnect:* unless the principal ARN matches the network-admin roles or the AWS SSO group you designate.
  • Require MFA for sensitive calls add an IAM condition BoolIfExists/aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent : true so console users must present MFA when modifying connections or virtual interfaces.
  • Monitor and audit stream CloudTrail events that match directconnect:* to CloudWatch Logs and set an EventBridge rule to alert on any caller outside your allow-list.
  • Review quarterly export IAM Access Analyzer last used data and remove unused Direct Connect permissions; update Region and tag conditions as your footprint changes.

Enforcing identity-based, least-privilege policies prevents unauthorized creation, deletion, or tampering of Direct Connect links that could disrupt hybrid connectivity.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?

countermeasure.name: Implement BGP hijacking protections
countermeasure.desc:
Protect Direct Connect virtual interfaces from BGP hijacking and route leaks by configuring both ends of the peering sessionyour on-prem router and AWSto accept only authenticated, pre-agreed prefixes and AS paths:

  1. enable BGP MD5 authentication
    • When you create or update the private or transit virtual interface, specify a BGP MD5 key (Amazon console Add BGP password).
    • Configure the matching password <secret> on your customer router so unauthenticated sessions are rejected.
  2. advertise and accept explicit prefix lists
    • On your router, use a prefix-list / route-map that only advertises the exact CIDR blocks you own (no more-specifics, no 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Apply an inbound filter that accepts only the AWS-announced RFC 1918 ranges (or any public space you expect) to prevent a poisoned route table.
  3. set max-prefix & as-path filters
    • neighbor <aws-peering-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5pick N slightly above the number of prefixes you legitimately expect (e.g., 5 % head-room).
    • Deny inbound prefixes whose AS_PATH is not exactly AS16509 (AWS) or the sequence you anticipate for a hosted connection.
  4. enable BFD and low hold timers
    • Turn on Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) and set aggressive timers (e.g., 300 ms, 3 multiplier) so hijacked or flapping sessions drop quickly.
    • If your device lacks BFD, reduce BGP keep-alive/hold timers (30 / 90 s) instead of the defaults.
  5. monitor and alert
    • Stream Direct Connect BGP state change and RouteChange CloudWatch metrics; alarm on BGPPeerDown, MaxPrefixesExceeded, or unexpected ASN/path events.
    • Log all BGP syslog messages on the customer router to a SIEM and detect new or more-specific routes instantly.
  6. review quarterly
    • Compare advertised prefixes against your IPAM source of truth; prune any stale routes.
    • Rotate the BGP MD5 key when staff leave or devices are replaced.

These layered controlsauthentication, strict prefix/as-path filtering, and rapid failure detectiongreatly reduce the chance that an attacker can hijack your Direct Connect traffic or inject malicious routes.

References

  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities
