countermeasure.name: Monitor and safeguard BGP routes
countermeasure.desc:
Continuously watch every Direct Connect BGP session and automatically flagor shut downany route change that could steer traffic to an unexpected destination.

  1. Stream BGP telemetry to CloudWatch
    • Enable the Direct Connect metrics BgpPeerState, BgpRouteFlapDampening, and BGPMaxPrefixesExceeded.
    • Create CloudWatch alarms that fire when a peer drops (BgpPeerState = 3), the route count jumps beyond the configured max-prefix value, or flapping exceeds a defined threshold.
  2. Log all route advertisements
    • On the customer router, export BGP UPDATE messages to a syslog or NetFlow collector; forward to your SIEM for real-time correlation.
    • Retain logs for at least 90 days so you can trace when and how a suspicious prefix entered the table.
  3. Detect drift with AWS Config & EventBridge
    • Deploy a custom AWS Config rule that compares the live list of accepted/advertised prefixes against your approved prefix list in IPAM.
    • When Config marks a resource NON_COMPLIANT, trigger an EventBridge rule that pages on-call staff andoptionallyruns an SSM Automation document to disable the virtual interface until reviewed.
  4. Implement route sanity checks
    • Use the routers prefix-list + route-map to drop any prefix longer than /24 or outside your owned CIDR blocks.
    • Set neighbor <peer-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5 to halt a session that suddenly advertises too many routes.
  5. Visualise and review
    • Build a CloudWatch dashboard that shows current prefix count, peer state, and alarm status for every virtual interface.
    • Review logs and metrics weekly; investigate any new ASN in the AS-PATH or unexplained rise in prefix count.

Proactive monitoring combined with automatic drift detection stops hijacked, leaked, or mis-typed routes before they impact production traffic.

References

  • Monitoring Direct Connect BGP sessions with CloudWatch metrics
  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Regularly audit Direct Connect configurations
countermeasure.desc:
At least once per quarterand after every network changegenerate and review a complete inventory of Direct Connect resources (connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associations, route filters, and BGP settings). Compare the live state against your infrastructure-as-code definitions and security baseline, then remediate drift immediately.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the snapshot
    • Run aws directconnect describe-* commands (or Terraform / CloudFormation drift-detect) from a scheduled pipeline; export JSON to an S3 bucket versioned for audit.
  2. Evaluate with AWS Config & Security Hub
    • Enable custom and managed Config rulesfor example, flag connections without BGP MD5 keys or VIFs without route filters. Send findings to Security Hub so they appear on your compliance dashboard.
  3. Cross-check critical attributes
    • Verify port speed, LOA expiry, VLAN IDs, SiteLink status, BGP ASN, maximum-prefix limits, and MD5 keys against your approved standards document or IPAM system.
  4. Document and remediate
    • Publish an audit report listing compliant items, drift, and required fixes. Track remediation tasks in your ticket system and confirm closure before the next audit cycle.

Regular, tool-driven audits prevent silent mis-configurations that could break redundancy, expose routes, or violate compliance requirements.

References

  • Evaluating Resources with AWS Config Rules

countermeasure.name: Use PFS-supported cipher suites
countermeasure.desc:
Whether youre calling the AWS APIs that manage Direct Connect or encrypting application payloads that traverse the circuit (for example, TLS to private NLBs or HTTPS to AWS service endpoints), configure the TLS stack so it negotiates only cipher suites that provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)that is, suites that use an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange such as ECDHE or DHE.

Implementation guidance

  1. restrict the client cipher list
    • On routers, firewalls, and application servers that initiate TLS sessions over Direct Connect, remove all static-key suites (RSA key exchange) and legacy ciphers (3DES, RC4).
    • Keep the list to modern suites such as TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, or (preferably) TLS 1.3 defaults.
  2. enforce on inbound endpoints
    • For load balancers and APIs hosted in AWS, select an ELB security policy that requires TLS 1.2/1.3 with PFS (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Reject client hellos that offer only non-PFS suites.
  3. verify with automated scans
    • Use openssl s_client -cipher 'aNULL' -connect host:443 and expect no handshake.
    • Schedule weekly or monthly scans (SSLLabs, AWS Inspector network assessments) to confirm no regressions.
  4. monitor for legacy fall-back
    • Enable CloudTrail data-events for ELB and look for TLSNegotiationError.
    • Set CloudWatch alarms on a spike in cipher-mismatch metricsan early sign that a client or server reverted to weak crypto.

PFS ensures that, even if a long-term private key is later compromised, past TLS sessions cannot be decryptedan essential property for protecting high-value traffic flowing over dedicated circuits like AWS Direct Connect.

References

  • Create an HTTPS listener for your Application Load Balancer

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackers network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

weakness.name: CWE-1103
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1103: Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components The product relies on third-party components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms.

weakness.name: CWE-119
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-119: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer The product performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

weakness.name: CWE-121
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-121: Stack-based Buffer Overflow A stack-based buffer overflow condition is a condition where the buffer being overwritten is allocated on the stack (i.e., is a local variable or, rarely, a parameter to a function).

weakness.name: CWE-1263
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1263: Improper Physical Access Control The product is designed with access restricted to certain information, but it does not sufficiently protect against an unauthorized actor with physical access to these areas. Sections of a product intended to have restricted access may be inadvertently or intentionally rendered accessible when the implemented physical protections are insufficient. The specific requirements around how robust the design of the physical protection mechanism needs to be depends on the type of product being protected. Selecting the correct physical protection mechanism and properly enforcing it through implementation and manufacturing are critical to the overall physical security of the product.

weakness.name: CWE-1283
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1283: Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

weakness.name: CWE-1326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1326: Missing Immutable Root of Trust in Hardware A missing immutable root of trust in the hardware results in the ability to bypass secure boot or execute untrusted or adversarial boot code.

weakness.name: CWE-1395
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1395: Dependency on Vulnerable Third-Party Component The product has a dependency on a third-party component that contains one or more known vulnerabilities.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-328
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-328: Use of Weak Hash The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack), find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack), or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack).

weakness.name: CWE-347
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-347: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-354
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-354: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-552
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-552: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties The product makes files or directories accessible to unauthorized actors, even though they should not be.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-927
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-927: Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications.

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.10.1-1: Event reporting format
countermeasure.desc:
Components report results of continuous security monitoring over the network using syslog-ng, together with a method for structuring message content in a human and machine-readable format such as JSON.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-10.4 CR 6.2

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.10.1-2: SIEM integration
countermeasure.desc:
Components are able to demonstrate the capability to report to at least one well-known Security Information and Event Management system (SIEM), for example including but not limited to: Splunk, Verve OT/ICS SIEM, Wazuh and LogESP.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-10.4 CR 6.2

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.11.1-1: Randomness for generated security parameters
countermeasure.desc: Supplier-assigned passwords and keys for IIoT devices and gateways are generated in accordance with requirements on random number generators defined under IIoT PR 4.1.1-1 regarding cryptographic techniques.

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.1.1-1: Cryptographic techniques
countermeasure.desc:
Cryptographic algorithms, including key lengths selected and random number generation methods used, conform to ISO/IEC 19790, or conform to an approved national or regional modification to Annex C of ISO/IEC 19790 (noting that such modifications are permitted by ISO/IEC 19790). There should be no reliance on proprietary or modified cryptographic algorithms. The following are examples of documents that provide conforming methods: For the United States, methods referenced in FIPS-140-3 'Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules' fall under this practice. FIPS-140-3 references a list of algorithms in NIST SP 800-140C revision 1 'CMVP Validation Authority Updates to ISO/IEC 24759' and the status of their acceptance in NIST SP 800-131A revision 2 'Transitioning the Use of Cryptographic Algorithms and Key Lengths.' For recommendations developed for the European Union, from ENISA, 'Algorithms, Key Size and Parameters Report. 2014 Recommendations' From Germany Federal Office for Information Security, BSI TR-02102-1: 'Cryptographic Mechanisms: Recommendations and Key Lengths' Version: 2022-1

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.5 CR 4.3

reference.name: ENISA Algorithms key size and parameters report
ENISA Post-Quantum Cryptography: Current state and quantum mitigation
ETSI TS 119 312 Electronic Signatures and Infrastructures (ESI); Cryptographic Suites
ISO 19790 Security requirements for cryptographic modules
Quantum Computing While Mitigating Risks to Vulnerable Cryptographic Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.1-1: Compartmentalize control functions
countermeasure.desc: The component architecture has a dedicated compartment or compartments for any essential functions and associated input and output.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.1-2: Resource allocation to essential function compartments
countermeasure.desc: If a component hosts both essential functions and non-essential functions using a compartmentalization technology, the component uses the resource allocation capabilities of that technology to allocate, monitor, and limit computing, storage and I/O resources available to non-essential functions of the component.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1: Separated security functions
countermeasure.desc: For all IIoT components, the following security functions are separated from other component functions: Setting and storage of credentials for component users; Verifying user credentials, such as certificate chain validation; Generation, changing and storage of keys; Encryption of data for communication or storage; Perform hash functions used for integrity checking under IIoT PR 4.5.1-2.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-2: Mechanism for security function separation
countermeasure.desc: Separation of the security functions as listed in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1 is achieved by either: Implementation on certified TPM 2.0 hardware; Use of a trusted execution environment (TEE) comprised of hardware and/or software that separates all persistent and non-persistent data storage and processing for the set of functions listed in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1 from other component functions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1034 - Limit Hardware Installation

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-3: Advanced tier mechanism for security function separation
countermeasure.desc: For high security IIoT components (represented in ICSA as Advanced tier), the security functions described in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1 are implemented in certified TPM hardware.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1034 - Limit Hardware Installation

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-1: Least privilege compartment interaction
countermeasure.desc: Policies enforceable by the compartmentalization technology limit interactions between compartments for least privilege.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-2: Residual threats due to compartment interactions
countermeasure.desc: The threat model for the component considers any threats due to inter-compartment interactions that remain after applying the policy enforcement provided by the compartmentalization technology, as described in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-1. The threat model also considers any threats that could result in bypassing that policy enforcement. Where indicated by the threat model, controls in addition to those provided by the compartmentalization technology are used to limit interactions between compartments. Examples are application of POSIX directory and file access control lists, or mandatory access control capabilities provided by the host operating system, such as SELinux or AppArmor (NIST SP 800-190 4.4.3). NOTE For example, additional controls might be added in the case where a component is unable to detect anomalous behavior as described in IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-6.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-3: Security benchmarking for compartmentalization
countermeasure.desc: If a commonly accepted security benchmark is available for a compartmentalization technology used by the component, conformance with the benchmark is evaluated by the supplier to identify and address any vulnerabilities indicated by nonconformance. Examples of such benchmarks are the CIS Docker, Kubernetes, LXD, and VMware Benchmarks. (NIST SP 800-190 4.4.3)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.4-1: Identify compartment source for communication
countermeasure.desc: Monitoring of network traffic outbound from the component or outbound communication internal to the component from a compartment, can identify the originating compartment, to support detection of anomalous traffic and incident handling. (NIST SP 800-190 4.4.2)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.4-2: Detect compartment infrastructure attack
countermeasure.desc: A component using compartmentalization methods has the capability to detect and log user activity that may indicate unauthorized actions using the compartmentalization infrastructure that can affect the compartments, for example by gaining privileged access to orchestration capabilities or the hypervisor. (NIST SP 800-190 4.5.4)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.2-1: Use bare metal hypervisor
countermeasure.desc: The component uses a bare metal hypervisor and not a hosted hypervisor. (2.2)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.2-2: Hypervisor physical protection
countermeasure.desc: Physical access to the component alone does not enable the ability to access the hypervisor. (4.1)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.2-3: Access control for hypervisor
countermeasure.desc: User access to the hypervisor is protected at a minimum with the same strength authentication as any application that will run on the device. (4.1)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-1: Use container-specific OS
countermeasure.desc: Where feasible, a component uses a container-specific OS minimized to run containerized software, to host its containers. If a component using containerization uses a full OS as a host, the supplier has a documented process they use for hardening the OS prior to product delivery. Further hardening guidance for the user is provided in cases where completion of hardening by the supplier prior to delivery is technically infeasible (such as when user-supplied software may be added to the product and may entail further hardening steps). (4.5.1)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-2: Containers non-privileged
countermeasure.desc: Containers not used for orchestration run as non-privileged users on their host OS. (4.1.2)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-3: No remote shells
countermeasure.desc: SSH or other remote administration shells are not enabled for communication to a container. (4.1.2)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-4: No data values in container
countermeasure.desc: A container does not include specific data values, rather it includes configuration information that allows the container to locate data it creates or uses. (2.1, 3.1.4).

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-5: No host file system mounted by container
countermeasure.desc: A container does not allow a host file system mount function. (4.5.5)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-6: Detect anomalous container behavior
countermeasure.desc: Containers are profiled, with automated tools where possible, so that anomalous container behavior may be detected and logged, such as: (4.4.4) ;Invalid or unexpected process execution; Invalid or unexpected system calls; Changes to protected configuration files and binaries; Writes to unexpected locations and file types ; Creation of unexpected network listeners ; Traffic sent to unexpected network destinations ; Presence or execution of files with unexpected types or sources ; Malware storage or execution.

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.3.1-1: Remote human user authentication methods
countermeasure.desc:
Multifactor or certificate-based authentication is used for remote human access to the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-5.3 CR 1.1

reference.name: ENISA Baseline Security Recommendations for IoT

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.4.1-1: Non-human user authentication methods
countermeasure.desc: Software processes and devices that access the component via an untrusted network use certificate-based credentials, to uniquely identify and authenticate themselves to the component.

reference.name: ENISA Baseline Security Recommendations for IoT
Industrial Internet of Things - Volume G4: Security Framework
The Seven Properties of Highly Secure Devices

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-1: Store initial file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
A facility is provided which is triggered at first bootup of the component, to calculate and store initial 'good' values of a cryptographic hash function applied to each of a baseline set of component files configured by the supplier as selected for integrity checking. At a minimum the baseline set of files will include all critical files.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-2: Compare current to stored file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
An integrity check function is provided locally or remotely, to calculate hash values for the current versions of selected files from the baseline set that are present on the component, and compare them to stored values, during component runtime.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-3: Report differences current to stored file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
Integrity function output that states whether or not differences are found between the current and stored hash values for selected files, is provided to a remote human interface.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-4: Triggers for integrity checking
countermeasure.desc:
The integrity check function is triggered in at least one of the following ways: By remote request, on-demand, for all selected files; According to a remote scheduling capability, for all selected files; Automatically, for files as they are used.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-5: Hash function for integrity check
countermeasure.desc:
The hash function used is approved by a national or regional authority, as described in IIoT PR 4.1.1-1.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-6: Changing stored file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
A facility is provided to update stored hash values for files that have authorized modifications, that does not require local access to the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-7: Add or delete stored hash values
countermeasure.desc:
If any of the critical files of the component can be added or deleted, or change file identifiers, then a facility is provided that allows an authorized user to add or delete files configured for integrity checking that does not require local access to the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.6.1-1: Non-persistent memory overflow protection
countermeasure.desc: Kernel and user space non-persistent memory structures including the call stack and counters are protected from overflow attacks. An example method for protecting the call stack is a stack canary. Structures used to track memory in use and free are protected from unauthorized manipulation.

reference.name: stack canaries - gingerly sidestepping the cage

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.6.1-2: Protect from unauthorized writes to non-persistent memory
countermeasure.desc: The component protects non-persistent memory from unauthorized changes using memory-region protection and monitoring, or RAM encryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.6.1-3: Protect from unauthorized writes to security software and data in non-persistent memory
countermeasure.desc: The component protects the integrity of security software and/or related data in non-persistent memory using the generic memory protection methods described in IIoT PR 4.6.1-2, dedicated hardware protection for keys, and/or a virtual or physical CPU or execution environment dedicated to security functions (Trusted Execution Environment, TEE).

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.7.1-1: Communication protocols
countermeasure.desc:
One or more of the following protocols is used for protecting the confidentiality, integrity and authenticity of data transmitted and received by the component over an untrusted network: TLS; DTLS; IPsec; SSH, DDS.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.3 CR 3.1, CR 3.1 RE 1

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1B

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.8.1-1: Encrypt confidential data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
For any data for which explicit read authorization is supported, the component stores only encrypted versions of this data in persistent storage. Examples of possible implementations are: Data is encrypted before storing as individual files in flash memory. Data is stored in an encrypted filesystem container. Data is stored in a self-encrypting drive.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1A

reference.name: ENISA Baseline Security Recommendations for IoT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.8.1-2: Approved cryptography for data at rest encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Encryption of confidential data placed in persistent storage uses an encryption function approved by a national or regional authority, as described in IIoT PR 4.1.1-1.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1A

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.8.1-3: Unique keys for data at rest encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Keys used for encryption of confidential data for persistent storage are unique to each instance of the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1A

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.9.1-1: IIoT component log events
countermeasure.desc:
The component logs security events that include but are not limited to the following, or provides data to another IIoT system element or SIEM to support this logging: ; Flooding attack at network layer on interface to untrusted network ; Flooding attack at application layer on interface to untrusted network ; Account locked out manually or automatically for any reason ; Attempt by any human or non-human user to perform action not authorized (special case of IEC 62443-4-2 CR 2.8 access control event) ; Unusual or unexpected input data rejected by component ; Disallowed attempted data flow between zones internal to the component ; Related cloud application unreachable ; Time since last device reboot ; Failure of integrity check ; Events defined by applications added to the device, where applications added are consistent with supplier recommendations in user documentation.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-10.4 CR 6.2

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion
threat.desc: Uncontrolled resource consumption may allow attackers to exhaust system resources, leading to denial of service

weakness.name: CWE-1103
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1103: Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components The product relies on third-party components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms.

weakness.name: CWE-119
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-119: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer The product performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

weakness.name: CWE-121
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-121: Stack-based Buffer Overflow A stack-based buffer overflow condition is a condition where the buffer being overwritten is allocated on the stack (i.e., is a local variable or, rarely, a parameter to a function).

weakness.name: CWE-1263
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1263: Improper Physical Access Control The product is designed with access restricted to certain information, but it does not sufficiently protect against an unauthorized actor with physical access to these areas. Sections of a product intended to have restricted access may be inadvertently or intentionally rendered accessible when the implemented physical protections are insufficient. The specific requirements around how robust the design of the physical protection mechanism needs to be depends on the type of product being protected. Selecting the correct physical protection mechanism and properly enforcing it through implementation and manufacturing are critical to the overall physical security of the product.

weakness.name: CWE-1283
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1283: Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

weakness.name: CWE-1326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1326: Missing Immutable Root of Trust in Hardware A missing immutable root of trust in the hardware results in the ability to bypass secure boot or execute untrusted or adversarial boot code.

weakness.name: CWE-1395
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1395: Dependency on Vulnerable Third-Party Component The product has a dependency on a third-party component that contains one or more known vulnerabilities.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-328
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-328: Use of Weak Hash The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack), find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack), or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack).

weakness.name: CWE-347
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-347: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-354
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-354: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-552
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-552: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties The product makes files or directories accessible to unauthorized actors, even though they should not be.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-927
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-927: Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications.

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.10.1-1: Event reporting format
countermeasure.desc:
Components report results of continuous security monitoring over the network using syslog-ng, together with a method for structuring message content in a human and machine-readable format such as JSON.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-10.4 CR 6.2

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.10.1-2: SIEM integration
countermeasure.desc:
Components are able to demonstrate the capability to report to at least one well-known Security Information and Event Management system (SIEM), for example including but not limited to: Splunk, Verve OT/ICS SIEM, Wazuh and LogESP.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-10.4 CR 6.2

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.11.1-1: Randomness for generated security parameters
countermeasure.desc: Supplier-assigned passwords and keys for IIoT devices and gateways are generated in accordance with requirements on random number generators defined under IIoT PR 4.1.1-1 regarding cryptographic techniques.

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.1.1-1: Cryptographic techniques
countermeasure.desc:
Cryptographic algorithms, including key lengths selected and random number generation methods used, conform to ISO/IEC 19790, or conform to an approved national or regional modification to Annex C of ISO/IEC 19790 (noting that such modifications are permitted by ISO/IEC 19790). There should be no reliance on proprietary or modified cryptographic algorithms. The following are examples of documents that provide conforming methods: For the United States, methods referenced in FIPS-140-3 'Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules' fall under this practice. FIPS-140-3 references a list of algorithms in NIST SP 800-140C revision 1 'CMVP Validation Authority Updates to ISO/IEC 24759' and the status of their acceptance in NIST SP 800-131A revision 2 'Transitioning the Use of Cryptographic Algorithms and Key Lengths.' For recommendations developed for the European Union, from ENISA, 'Algorithms, Key Size and Parameters Report. 2014 Recommendations' From Germany Federal Office for Information Security, BSI TR-02102-1: 'Cryptographic Mechanisms: Recommendations and Key Lengths' Version: 2022-1

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.5 CR 4.3

reference.name: ENISA Algorithms key size and parameters report
ENISA Post-Quantum Cryptography: Current state and quantum mitigation
ETSI TS 119 312 Electronic Signatures and Infrastructures (ESI); Cryptographic Suites
ISO 19790 Security requirements for cryptographic modules
Quantum Computing While Mitigating Risks to Vulnerable Cryptographic Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.1-1: Compartmentalize control functions
countermeasure.desc: The component architecture has a dedicated compartment or compartments for any essential functions and associated input and output.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.1-2: Resource allocation to essential function compartments
countermeasure.desc: If a component hosts both essential functions and non-essential functions using a compartmentalization technology, the component uses the resource allocation capabilities of that technology to allocate, monitor, and limit computing, storage and I/O resources available to non-essential functions of the component.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1: Separated security functions
countermeasure.desc: For all IIoT components, the following security functions are separated from other component functions: Setting and storage of credentials for component users; Verifying user credentials, such as certificate chain validation; Generation, changing and storage of keys; Encryption of data for communication or storage; Perform hash functions used for integrity checking under IIoT PR 4.5.1-2.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-2: Mechanism for security function separation
countermeasure.desc: Separation of the security functions as listed in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1 is achieved by either: Implementation on certified TPM 2.0 hardware; Use of a trusted execution environment (TEE) comprised of hardware and/or software that separates all persistent and non-persistent data storage and processing for the set of functions listed in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1 from other component functions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1034 - Limit Hardware Installation

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-3: Advanced tier mechanism for security function separation
countermeasure.desc: For high security IIoT components (represented in ICSA as Advanced tier), the security functions described in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.2-1 are implemented in certified TPM hardware.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1034 - Limit Hardware Installation

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-1: Least privilege compartment interaction
countermeasure.desc: Policies enforceable by the compartmentalization technology limit interactions between compartments for least privilege.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-2: Residual threats due to compartment interactions
countermeasure.desc: The threat model for the component considers any threats due to inter-compartment interactions that remain after applying the policy enforcement provided by the compartmentalization technology, as described in IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-1. The threat model also considers any threats that could result in bypassing that policy enforcement. Where indicated by the threat model, controls in addition to those provided by the compartmentalization technology are used to limit interactions between compartments. Examples are application of POSIX directory and file access control lists, or mandatory access control capabilities provided by the host operating system, such as SELinux or AppArmor (NIST SP 800-190 4.4.3). NOTE For example, additional controls might be added in the case where a component is unable to detect anomalous behavior as described in IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-6.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.3-3: Security benchmarking for compartmentalization
countermeasure.desc: If a commonly accepted security benchmark is available for a compartmentalization technology used by the component, conformance with the benchmark is evaluated by the supplier to identify and address any vulnerabilities indicated by nonconformance. Examples of such benchmarks are the CIS Docker, Kubernetes, LXD, and VMware Benchmarks. (NIST SP 800-190 4.4.3)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.4-1: Identify compartment source for communication
countermeasure.desc: Monitoring of network traffic outbound from the component or outbound communication internal to the component from a compartment, can identify the originating compartment, to support detection of anomalous traffic and incident handling. (NIST SP 800-190 4.4.2)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.1.4-2: Detect compartment infrastructure attack
countermeasure.desc: A component using compartmentalization methods has the capability to detect and log user activity that may indicate unauthorized actions using the compartmentalization infrastructure that can affect the compartments, for example by gaining privileged access to orchestration capabilities or the hypervisor. (NIST SP 800-190 4.5.4)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.2-1: Use bare metal hypervisor
countermeasure.desc: The component uses a bare metal hypervisor and not a hosted hypervisor. (2.2)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.2-2: Hypervisor physical protection
countermeasure.desc: Physical access to the component alone does not enable the ability to access the hypervisor. (4.1)

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.2-3: Access control for hypervisor
countermeasure.desc: User access to the hypervisor is protected at a minimum with the same strength authentication as any application that will run on the device. (4.1)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-1: Use container-specific OS
countermeasure.desc: Where feasible, a component uses a container-specific OS minimized to run containerized software, to host its containers. If a component using containerization uses a full OS as a host, the supplier has a documented process they use for hardening the OS prior to product delivery. Further hardening guidance for the user is provided in cases where completion of hardening by the supplier prior to delivery is technically infeasible (such as when user-supplied software may be added to the product and may entail further hardening steps). (4.5.1)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-2: Containers non-privileged
countermeasure.desc: Containers not used for orchestration run as non-privileged users on their host OS. (4.1.2)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-3: No remote shells
countermeasure.desc: SSH or other remote administration shells are not enabled for communication to a container. (4.1.2)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-4: No data values in container
countermeasure.desc: A container does not include specific data values, rather it includes configuration information that allows the container to locate data it creates or uses. (2.1, 3.1.4).

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-5: No host file system mounted by container
countermeasure.desc: A container does not allow a host file system mount function. (4.5.5)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.2.1.3-6: Detect anomalous container behavior
countermeasure.desc: Containers are profiled, with automated tools where possible, so that anomalous container behavior may be detected and logged, such as: (4.4.4) ;Invalid or unexpected process execution; Invalid or unexpected system calls; Changes to protected configuration files and binaries; Writes to unexpected locations and file types ; Creation of unexpected network listeners ; Traffic sent to unexpected network destinations ; Presence or execution of files with unexpected types or sources ; Malware storage or execution.

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.3.1-1: Remote human user authentication methods
countermeasure.desc:
Multifactor or certificate-based authentication is used for remote human access to the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-5.3 CR 1.1

reference.name: ENISA Baseline Security Recommendations for IoT

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.4.1-1: Non-human user authentication methods
countermeasure.desc: Software processes and devices that access the component via an untrusted network use certificate-based credentials, to uniquely identify and authenticate themselves to the component.

reference.name: ENISA Baseline Security Recommendations for IoT
Industrial Internet of Things - Volume G4: Security Framework
The Seven Properties of Highly Secure Devices

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-1: Store initial file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
A facility is provided which is triggered at first bootup of the component, to calculate and store initial 'good' values of a cryptographic hash function applied to each of a baseline set of component files configured by the supplier as selected for integrity checking. At a minimum the baseline set of files will include all critical files.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-2: Compare current to stored file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
An integrity check function is provided locally or remotely, to calculate hash values for the current versions of selected files from the baseline set that are present on the component, and compare them to stored values, during component runtime.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-3: Report differences current to stored file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
Integrity function output that states whether or not differences are found between the current and stored hash values for selected files, is provided to a remote human interface.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-4: Triggers for integrity checking
countermeasure.desc:
The integrity check function is triggered in at least one of the following ways: By remote request, on-demand, for all selected files; According to a remote scheduling capability, for all selected files; Automatically, for files as they are used.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-5: Hash function for integrity check
countermeasure.desc:
The hash function used is approved by a national or regional authority, as described in IIoT PR 4.1.1-1.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-6: Changing stored file hash values
countermeasure.desc:
A facility is provided to update stored hash values for files that have authorized modifications, that does not require local access to the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.5.1-7: Add or delete stored hash values
countermeasure.desc:
If any of the critical files of the component can be added or deleted, or change file identifiers, then a facility is provided that allows an authorized user to add or delete files configured for integrity checking that does not require local access to the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.6 CR 3.4

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.6.1-1: Non-persistent memory overflow protection
countermeasure.desc: Kernel and user space non-persistent memory structures including the call stack and counters are protected from overflow attacks. An example method for protecting the call stack is a stack canary. Structures used to track memory in use and free are protected from unauthorized manipulation.

reference.name: stack canaries - gingerly sidestepping the cage

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.6.1-2: Protect from unauthorized writes to non-persistent memory
countermeasure.desc: The component protects non-persistent memory from unauthorized changes using memory-region protection and monitoring, or RAM encryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.6.1-3: Protect from unauthorized writes to security software and data in non-persistent memory
countermeasure.desc: The component protects the integrity of security software and/or related data in non-persistent memory using the generic memory protection methods described in IIoT PR 4.6.1-2, dedicated hardware protection for keys, and/or a virtual or physical CPU or execution environment dedicated to security functions (Trusted Execution Environment, TEE).

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.7.1-1: Communication protocols
countermeasure.desc:
One or more of the following protocols is used for protecting the confidentiality, integrity and authenticity of data transmitted and received by the component over an untrusted network: TLS; DTLS; IPsec; SSH, DDS.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-7.3 CR 3.1, CR 3.1 RE 1

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1B

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.8.1-1: Encrypt confidential data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
For any data for which explicit read authorization is supported, the component stores only encrypted versions of this data in persistent storage. Examples of possible implementations are: Data is encrypted before storing as individual files in flash memory. Data is stored in an encrypted filesystem container. Data is stored in a self-encrypting drive.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1A

reference.name: ENISA Baseline Security Recommendations for IoT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.8.1-2: Approved cryptography for data at rest encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Encryption of confidential data placed in persistent storage uses an encryption function approved by a national or regional authority, as described in IIoT PR 4.1.1-1.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1A

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.8.1-3: Unique keys for data at rest encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Keys used for encryption of confidential data for persistent storage are unique to each instance of the component.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-8.3 CR 4.1A

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: IIoT PR 4.9.1-1: IIoT component log events
countermeasure.desc:
The component logs security events that include but are not limited to the following, or provides data to another IIoT system element or SIEM to support this logging: ; Flooding attack at network layer on interface to untrusted network ; Flooding attack at application layer on interface to untrusted network ; Account locked out manually or automatically for any reason ; Attempt by any human or non-human user to perform action not authorized (special case of IEC 62443-4-2 CR 2.8 access control event) ; Unusual or unexpected input data rejected by component ; Disallowed attempted data flow between zones internal to the component ; Related cloud application unreachable ; Time since last device reboot ; Failure of integrity check ; Events defined by applications added to the device, where applications added are consistent with supplier recommendations in user documentation.

iec-62443-4-2:2019-10.4 CR 6.2

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1127 - Trusted Developer Utilities Proxy Execution

threat.desc: Missing encryption of sensitive data can lead to data breaches

threat.desc: Use of implicit intent for sensitive communication can lead to unintended information exposure

threat.name: Unauthorized file access

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring, Undetected breaches
threat.desc: Insufficient logging can hinder the detection and response to security incidents

threat.desc: Insufficient logging can hinder the detection and response to security incidents

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1042 - Change Default File Association

threat.name: Tampered reports, Insufficient reporting
threat.desc: Insufficient logging and monitoring can result in undetected security incidents

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attack
threat.desc: Improper certificate validation can allow attackers to use fraudulent certificates for impersonation

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc: Weak authentication methods can result in unauthorized access to the device

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.
