customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single Availability Zone dependency causing regional service outage impact
threat.desc:
General threat description
Workloads located in a single AWS Availability Zone are exposed to disruptions resulting from zonal failures, scheduled maintenance, or capacity constraints, posing risks to service continuity and data accessibility.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Zonal failures may arise from natural disasters, hardware malfunctions, or network issues. Planned maintenance or sudden demand spikes may also contribute to decreased availability.
Impacts
The impacts include potential outages, temporary or permanent loss of data, degradation of application performance, and loss of trust or revenue resulting from service disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hardware failure within an Availability Zone causes a widespread outage, bringing down critical applications hosted in that zone. Alternatively, a planned maintenance event reduces resource availability, resulting in service degradation for all workloads relying exclusively on that zone.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Availability Zone identifier mismatch across accounts causing misplacement
threat.desc:
General threat description
Hardcoding the names of Availability Zones can lead to resources being placed in unintended physical zones due to the variability in how names map to physical zones across accounts, which can compromise redundancy and failover strategies.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unintentional misconfiguration by developers or operators, reliance on incorrect documentation, or automated deployment scripts that do not account for differing zone mappings.
Impacts
Potential lack of high availability, increased risk of resource failure in disasters, and compromised system reliability due to violated redundancy and failover assumptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A developer deploys instances to us-east-1a, assuming it corresponds to a specific physical zone across all accounts, but the mapping differs in their organizations AWS account, placing resources in the same physical zone as other critical systems. A failure in this zone leads to a cascading outage.

threat.name: Capacity and placement risk within an Availability Zone
threat.desc:
General threat description
Zonal capacity constraints or inflexible placement strategies can restrict the ability to scale or perform failovers during disruptions, leading to system downtime or reduced service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigurations, resource limitations, or improper distribution of workloads can exacerbate zonal constraints and lack of effective placement mechanisms.
Impacts
Reduced service availability, inability to recover from disruptions, and potential customer dissatisfaction due to reliability issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
A sudden increase in resource demand overwhelms a specific Availability Zone, and the inability to migrate workloads to another zone results in degraded performance or service outages. Alternatively, rigid placement strategies restrict scalability, preventing efficient allocation of resources across zones during high loads.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Subnet and route misconfiguration exposing Availability Zone resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) design can lead to unintended exposure of instances or services within an Availability Zone to networks or the internet, compromising isolation and security.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit shared route tables, misconfigured public subnets meant to be private, or overly permissive network ACLs to gain unauthorized access or disrupt services.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, unauthorized access, service disruptions, or exploitation of exposed resources for malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization accidentally configures a public subnet instead of a private one, inadvertently exposing critical services to the internet. Attackers notice and exploit misconfigured ACLs to access sensitive data or disrupt internal services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Cross-Availability Zone traffic exposure due to broad network rules
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overly permissive configurations in security groups or network ACLs can inadvertently create unintended cross-Availability Zone access paths, potentially increasing the impact of a compromise and expanding the blast radius.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or misconfigured resources can exploit permissive settings to traverse networks across zones, accessing unauthorized systems or data in other Availability Zones.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and escalation of security incidents across multiple zones, reducing the isolation benefits of Availability Zones.
Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured database in one zone with an overly permissive security group gets exploited by an attacker, who then pivots to access sensitive systems in other zones through unintended network paths, amplifying the impact of the event.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Uncontrolled internet egress from Availability Zone subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Instances in private subnets of an Availability Zone may inadvertently access the internet through shared NAT gateways or misconfigured routing, potentially exposing them to risks such as data exfiltration or unauthorized command-and-control activities if outbound traffic is not strictly controlled per zone.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured routing tables, overly permissive NAT gateway rules, or unmonitored outbound traffic within the private subnets to establish unauthorized communication channels with external entities.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized remote control of instances, or exploitation of the infrastructure for malicious activity, which could lead to financial, reputational, and operational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might exploit a misconfigured routing table to redirect traffic from instances to a malicious server on the internet, extracting sensitive information. Alternatively, compromised instances could use a shared NAT gateway to contact a command-and-control server, initiating further attacks or lateral movement within the environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient Availability Zone-aware logging and visibility
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient logging and monitoring granularity associated with Availability Zones can hinder prompt identification and management of zonal faults, unauthorized lateral movement, or configuration errors, weakening the efficacy of incident response.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploiting gaps in logging to move laterally between zones or leveraging undetected misconfigurations to compromise security.
Impacts
Delayed detection of security concerns, reduced incident response times, and increased potential for extensive damage or data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An undetected misconfiguration in one zone allows unauthorized access, and the lack of granular monitoring enables an attacker to move laterally to compromise other zones without being noticed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

component.name: Site-to-Site VPN
component.desc: AWS Site-to-Site VPN for secure connection.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure AWS Site-to-Site VPN to use AES-256 encryption with GCM mode
countermeasure.desc: Secure AWS Site-to-Site VPN connections by configuring them to use AES-256 encryption in Galois/Counter Mode (GCM). This ensures that all data transmitted between AWS and on-premises environments is encrypted with strong encryption algorithms, providing both data integrity and confidentiality. Configure both phases of the Internet Key Exchange (IKE) to utilize AES-256-GCM for maximum security during the VPN handshake and data transfer processes. Regularly review and update the VPN configuration to ensure compatibility with security best practices and evolving encryption standards.

reference.name: Tunnel options for your Site-to-Site VPN connection

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Monitor Site-to-Site VPN connections using AWS CloudWatch and VPC flow logs
countermeasure.desc: Implement continuous monitoring for AWS Site-to-Site VPN connections by enabling AWS CloudWatch and VPC flow logs. Configure CloudWatch to collect and analyze VPN connection metrics, such as tunnel status and connection duration, while VPC flow logs capture detailed information on traffic patterns. Set up alerts for unusual traffic behavior or unauthorized access attempts to ensure real-time detection of potential threats. Regularly review logs and use automated alerting to quickly respond to security incidents or anomalies in the VPN traffic.

SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Use Diffie-Hellman group 20 for secure key exchanges in AWS Site-to-Site VPN
countermeasure.desc: Configure AWS Site-to-Site VPN to use Diffie-Hellman (DH) group 20 during the Internet Key Exchange (IKE) setup to ensure stronger cryptographic protection. DH group 20 provides higher security by using a 384-bit elliptic curve for key exchanges, which helps mitigate vulnerabilities associated with lower-strength groups. This configuration reduces the risk of cryptographic attacks during VPN setup and maintains the confidentiality and integrity of the data exchanged. Regularly review the key exchange settings and upgrade to more secure groups as they become available to maintain a strong security posture.

reference.name: Tunnel options for your Site-to-Site VPN connection

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Use IKEv2 for setting up AWS Site-to-Site VPN tunnels
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Site-to-Site VPN tunnels are configured to use Internet Key Exchange version 2 (IKEv2) for enhanced security and efficiency over IKEv1. IKEv2 supports stronger encryption algorithms, better resilience to network changes, and faster reconnection times, making it a more secure and efficient choice for VPN tunnel setup. Configure both the AWS and customer gateway to use IKEv2, and regularly review VPN settings to ensure ongoing compliance with security best practices and modern encryption standards.

reference.name: AWS Site-to-Site VPN Now Supports IKEv2

countermeasure.name: Use traffic filtering and firewall rules to restrict VPN traffic to authorized IP ranges and protocols
countermeasure.desc: Configure traffic filtering and firewall rules to limit Site-to-Site VPN traffic to specific, authorized IP ranges and protocols. This ensures that only approved traffic flows through the VPN tunnel, minimizing the risk of unauthorized access or data leakage. Implement network access control lists (ACLs) and security group rules to define permissible traffic and block unwanted connections. Regularly review and update these rules based on organizational requirements to maintain strong network security and minimize exposure to potential attacks.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unrestricted VPN traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrestricted VPN traffic occurs when VPN tunnels are configured to allow all traffic without filtering, exposing the network to unnecessary risks. Without proper traffic controls, malicious actors or unauthorized users could gain access to sensitive resources and perform unauthorized actions within the network.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers or unauthorized users could exploit the open access provided by unrestricted VPN traffic. Common vectors include brute-force attacks, lateral movement within the network, or malware that utilizes the VPN tunnel for data exfiltration.

Impacts

Unrestricted VPN traffic can lead to unauthorized access to critical systems, data breaches, malware infections, and compliance violations. The lack of granular control increases the attack surface, making the network more vulnerable to internal and external threats.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A user gains VPN access but can reach more sensitive parts of the network than intended due to an overly permissive VPN configuration.
  • Scenario 2: An attacker compromises a user's credentials and uses the VPN to explore and escalate privileges within the network, accessing sensitive data or launching further attacks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Vulnerable IKE negotiation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Vulnerable Internet Key Exchange (IKE) negotiations occur when weak or outdated versions of the IKE protocol are used to establish a VPN connection. IKE vulnerabilities can be exploited during the VPN tunnel setup, leading to interception of key exchanges or man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromising the security of the VPN connection.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include attackers exploiting weaknesses in IKE versions, such as IKEv1, which is prone to known vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include intercepting IKE messages, brute-forcing Diffie-Hellman key exchanges, or manipulating the session to gain unauthorized access to the VPN.

Impacts

Successful exploitation of vulnerable IKE negotiations can lead to compromised VPN connections, interception of sensitive data, unauthorized access, or the ability to decrypt VPN traffic. This could result in data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and potential regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts IKEv1 negotiations and exploits known vulnerabilities to access the VPN traffic and gain unauthorized access to the network.
  • Scenario 2: During the IKE phase, an attacker uses a weak Diffie-Hellman group to compromise the key exchange, allowing them to decrypt sensitive data transmitted over the VPN.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1196 - Control Panel Items

threat.name: Inadequate key exchange mechanisms
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate key exchange mechanisms occur when weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms, such as low-strength Diffie-Hellman (DH) groups, are used during VPN negotiations. These vulnerabilities can compromise the security of the VPN, allowing attackers to intercept or decrypt key exchanges, resulting in unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers could exploit weaknesses in key exchange mechanisms by leveraging brute-force attacks, intercepting Diffie-Hellman key exchanges, or exploiting known vulnerabilities in outdated Internet Key Exchange (IKE) configurations. The use of weak DH groups or older IKE versions (e.g., IKEv1) exposes the system to cryptographic attacks.

Impacts

If the key exchange is compromised, attackers can potentially decrypt traffic, gain unauthorized access to encrypted data, or even impersonate trusted systems, leading to significant security breaches, data exposure, and non-compliance with security regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker takes advantage of a VPN tunnel using a low-strength Diffie-Hellman group to compromise the key exchange and decrypt sensitive data transmitted over the VPN.
  • Scenario 2: A network administrator uses an outdated IKE version (IKEv1) with known vulnerabilities, allowing an attacker to manipulate the key exchange and gain unauthorized access to encrypted communications.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Insecure VPN tunnels
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure VPN tunnels occur when weak encryption or misconfigurations leave data transmitted between on-premises systems and AWS vulnerable to interception or decryption.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers may exploit outdated encryption protocols, such as weak Diffie-Hellman groups, or use man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks to intercept or alter VPN traffic.

Impacts

Sensitive data exposure, unauthorized access to the network, and potential data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker exploits weak encryption in a VPN tunnel to intercept confidential communications.
  • Scenario 2: An outdated IKE version is compromised, allowing unauthorized access to encrypted data.

threat.name: Unmonitored VPN traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored VPN traffic occurs when there is insufficient logging or monitoring of data being transmitted over the AWS Site-to-Site VPN. Without proper oversight, suspicious or malicious activities, such as unauthorized access or data exfiltration, can go undetected, potentially leading to data breaches or network compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers leveraging weaknesses in the VPN configuration, or insiders transmitting unauthorized traffic. Attack vectors may include attempts to bypass security controls, malware using VPN traffic to exfiltrate data, or unauthorized access due to lack of traffic inspection.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents, unauthorized access, and data breaches, leading to financial loss, legal repercussions, and reputational damage. Organizations may fail to meet compliance requirements that mandate monitoring of sensitive traffic.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A malware-infected device uses the VPN tunnel to exfiltrate data. Without monitoring in place, the malicious activity remains undetected.
  • Scenario 2: An unauthorized user gains access to the VPN but remains unnoticed due to a lack of real-time traffic monitoring, allowing lateral movement within the network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol
